game-hours: 462.5
review: Ah, TF2, the most popular game on Steam... Team Fortress 2 is a First-Person Shooter, but it sets itself apart from the other FPS games out there, like COD, Battlefield, Medal of Honor, and so on. It does this with class strengths and class weaknesses. And hats. Don't forget the hats. There are nine classes in the game, each with a specific job and strengths against certain other classes (EX: When you play as Engineer you're supposed to build Sentry Guns to defend an area and are good against pretty much anything that has to fight you directly, while Demoman was made as a counter to the Engineer with his bouncing pipe bombs). I won't go into detail about which class does what (except I kinda just did) since doubtlessly other reviewers have done that already. There's several different modes, for both PvP and PvE. You have CTF, Control Points, Payload (where you push a bomb into the other team's base and set it off as one team, whilst the other team tries to defend their base), Arena (try to kill everyone on the other team before they do the same), and a couple others. The game has a TON of people playing it, loads of guides (here on Steam and on Youtube), a dedicated wiki, and loads of customization options. There's even one where you can give your character a sword! As well you have cosmetic options. You can buy hats for your characters to make them look like the dignified, manly killers they truly are. You can also find them sometimes. The entire community is bonkers for hats (well, the entire community except Shibby2142). People have shelled out 100s of dollars for an unusual hat. Overall, fun game, definitely worth your time considering you can put stuff on the Steam Market to earn a little extra pocket change.

game-hours: 659.6
review: Dear reader, have you ever played DayZ, spawned and was killed by some man (or woman, i dont discriminate) with an ungodly amount of weapons? Perhaps you played Call of Duty, and helplessly watched as your entire team was killed by someone throwin a grenade. Shenanigans are fun when you have the say in who it goes to, but what if you wanted a game that actually requires skill? Look no further than TF2! this is a game that is serious, but doesnt take itself too seriously. With Valve servers you can duke it out with other players in a fair match, or play in a community made server and bend the rules till your hearts content! The game lacks the weapons that most FPSs base themselves on. To do the most damage you need to get up close and personal with your scatter gun, and dash away before you get yourself killed. This game bases itself and its game play on nine classes, with their own individuel story, perks, stats, and weapon setups. Each class requires different skills to play. Example to effectivly play a good soldier, one would need to understand the speed of the rocket, and the direction the enemy is going. Using this infromation, plus a couple others, you can dispatch this enemy and move onto the next. Not into the whole thinking before doing thing? TF2 has a class for that! Play as the pyro or medic. Either way this game has something for everyone. Those who want a serious game play experiance can use the Highlander servers. Those who want to look fly and nifty can go on trade servers. Why are you not downloading this game? Do you not like fun? I promise you there is a server for you, there is a fandom for you, and there is a faction for you! ThatBronyGuy thinks this game is swell.

review: So, If you are looking for an amazingly fun FPS that is both fun and competitive, then this is the game for you. Team fortress 2 is a FREE online FPS which also has hats. Those things should be plenty to make you wanna download it but, just in case, here are my findings from nearly 1000 hours of playing: 1. You will near-always find a server near you, Valve has every well connected area covered. 2. There will be servers that are FUN servers and others will be COMPETITIVE, this means whether you're looking for a fun, taunt kill everyone match or a competitive 32 man cluster flock, you'll find it. 3. The weapons are amazingly balanced, but also fun. Sure everyone loves to hate the Phlog, Pompson e.t.c, once you find a server with a good community, you'll feel right at home. 4. It has one of the best free to play models of any game I have seen. You don't need to spend a penny to get all of the non-cosmetic items in the game. However there are small benefits for spending 0.29 on a can of pop. 5. HATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATSHATS So, yea. In short this game is #1 on my recommended FTP games because it is balanced, competitive, FREE and, most importantly, FUN :sticky:

review: I have played TF2 since February 2012, and ever since it's kind of been one of those games; "Oh, I don't know what to do. I might just play TF2". A lot of people (including some of my friends) said that this is just one of those Pay-2-Win games but it really isn't. Weapons drop for everyone, randomly. You don't need hats or freaking Unusuals to win a match, you're just good at the game. Most of my friends that play TF2 think that players who wear Gibuses and Pyrovision Goggles are just plain failure, but I was like that too. Nowadays there's this impression that if a player has Premium on TF2 (which btw you can get it by just purchasing one item in the shop) they're immediately very good at the game... It's not like that. I have some complaints though. Unofficial premium servers; that's right, Saigns. Those are Pay-2-Win servers. Never play in one of these. Blacklist all of them.

game-hours: 3008.3
review: YAY TF2
game-hours: 417.2
review: This game is great in a lot of aspects. First lets talk about the gameplay. Team Fortress 2 offers amazing gameplay with fun classes to play. There are currently 9 classes and each class offers a different role to the team. Whether it be defense, offense, or support. It's a fun game to play with friends on multiplayer. You can play on certified Valve Maps and even community made maps. Another good aspect of the game is the shop. The shop allows players to buy and access items, taunts, and various hats to use in game. Another neat factor I like is that for weapons, you can run a test run to try out the weapon for a week. But this doesn't make the game a, "Pay-to-win" game. Other items can counter others, This brings me to another great aspect: Customization. One of the most versatile and best things in TF2. The ability to customize your characters to make it your own. Various weapons to combine in a "loadout." With an option of making 4 loadouts for each class! Also, the customization factor allows you to put hats, different outfits, and various other cosmetics on your character to make them look unique. There are also weapons that count your kills for you, and unusual items that have special effects, rather than just plain old replicas of the item itself. Valve is NOT lazy with this game. Currently putting out updates and patches occasionally with new weapons, cosmetics, items, etc. to make the game interesting, and not make it stay bland. TF2 also provides a trading community. A place where players can trade their items to get new ones. A very effective way of getting what you want. But, unfortunately, you have to buy something from the shop first with real money in order to trade. :( There are also achievements to get for various classes and events to make the game a bit of a challenge. Anyways, there are also Steam Workshops where players can create their own items. Not only for TF2, but for other games too. Sometimes, your items can even get implemented at Valve's request. All in all, TF2 is a great, cartoonish style, free to play first person shooter with a lot of customization to make it fun. The multiplayer is just excellent with the ability to interact with other players on excellent maps. The fact that the community takes part in helping and making new things for the game is amazing. It is just a great game overall, with a lot of fun packed adventures! I HIGHLY recommend this game. Rating: 9/10

review: This game is extremely fun and highly addictive. The only downside is that the players who bought the game before it was free are really butthurt. If you are a free-to-play player, it is likely that the paid players will be on your  and treat you like you're the new kid in class. My advice: ignore them. They're just silly people who are butthurt that they had to spend money and you didn't. Arguements are easy to get into in this game, so you're best option is to just play the game and avoid all communications unless someone seems really nice. :3 Gameplay wise, you can never go wrong in this game (unless dealing with hackers). The game is incredibly balanced so that even if you're a new player using default weapons, you can still land yourself on the top of the scoreboard. Just don't get cocky. People don't like that. Have fun, be nice, and you may be rewarded with some sweet gear. 9/10 it was okay

review: Team Fortress 2. TF2. Call it what you want, but it'll always be my favorite game. TF2 is a team-base shooter game about a butt-load of different game modes. review: I could, and sometimes do, play this game all day without stopping. It never gets old. The graphics are awesome, the characters are hilarious, and there's a lot of diversity in each of them. One of the few games where you rely on the strengths of everyone to win, but can still have a lot of fun even when you lose. It doesn't take a lot of learning to figure out how to get going, and the gameplay is solid. They continually add in new weapons and features, as well as new maps, and with it as cheap as it is, it's definitely worth picking up.

game-hours: 989.0
review: I played this game and i was instantly captivated by it it is brilliant the unlockables the fast paced action and the enjoyable characters all with their own nationalities (sniper is australian heavy is russian etc) the community is great unlike some other gaming communities (runescape) team fortress 2 is filled with friendly people everywhere you go whatever server you play on there is always atleast 11 friendly people in a game of 14 apart from the non stop tdm feel on team fortress 2 there is also another side to it..... the trading side you can trade to get whatever item you want although it will take some hard work. you can get stranges killstreaks unusuals botkilers hats miscs and taunts. to see what all these things are you will have to play it for yourself. tf2 has such a great trading side to it that it even has it's own currency. you get unlockable weapons every 40 mins to 2 hrs that you play. two of the weapons from the same class will make a scrap metal 3 scrap is a reclaimed 3 reclaimed is a refined in trading reclaimed and refined metal are often referred to as rec and ref. and one little thing. you need to buy something from the in game shop for anything you have to be tradable. it is a bit of a letdown but honestly it was worth it since tf2 itself is free-to-play. back to the tdm side. not all the gamemodes are tdm as a matter of fact it is only an opyion available when you make a server. the gamemodes are control points, capture the flag, king of the hill, payload race and a couple of others that i forget. i am not going to go through what you can do and what the objectives are in each of these gamemodes. i am going to stop this review here and say i would definately recommend this game to anyone looking for a good first person shooter with a bit of a comedic feel (i am aware i made comedic up i couldn't find the right word) not very high gore very fast paces and plenty of unlockables and trades to be had. so yeah play it it's good fun!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

review: This is easily one of my personal favorite games I have ever played. I watched a couple of TF2-related videos on Youtube and thought: Huh. Everyone likes this. I could give it a try, but... What if it's like Call of Duty where it's literally the same thing that has already been done thousand times? Then, I saw Top Nine Team Fortress by Fawful's Minion. I was impressed. There was variation, things that weren't possible in the real world, no annoying blood effects on your screen when you were hurt. I downloaded Steam and the game. Despite it eating up a boatload of memory and lots of my time, I didn't regret my choice and will probably never start to regret it.

review: I wouldn't really fully recommend this to any old school gamer, but for free it's one of the best games ever. VALVe have done an amazing job making their games available free to play for all, with premium access to the Orange Box buyers, so now VALVe can bring in lots more players that weren't previously aware of their awesome games. Only problem I find with it is most of the community, and the unseriousness of the gameplay. The hats, the items, they just don't do it for me. TFC was all about teamwork, shooting, and plain seriousness. Whereas with TF2, it's all just joking, cartoon-y, hats, items, trading...You get the point. I like the game, and I still recommend it to everyone, but It's just not for me.

review: This game is one I've put a lot of precious time (and money) into. Characters and cosmedics are constantly developing and improving. And although the general 'gaming' community is reviewed poorly is some cases, the judges have shunned the smaller communities within this well known game. Slender Fortress, Parkour Fortress and smaller trade server groups all have great little societies that they're able to manage. Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone familar to an FPS, but I'd caution them of the F2P system. I'd convert to a P2P by any means necessary, whether buying a hat or a giftapult. Other than that, great game, Valve.

game-hours: 295.7
review: Okay, unless you have some operating system other than Windows, Mac OS, or Linux, you really have no excuse whatsoever to not own this game. I used to think I was not a fan of first-person shooters. I was wrong. This game has scads and scads of humor that kept me going through the early learning periods, allowing me to laugh off my failures instead of get frustrated at them. What I didn't realize at the time, though, was I was still learning how to play. And by the time the humor was wearing thin, skill was taking over. I might have only been classified as 'competent', but I wasn't mindlessly killing myself over and over. I was making a difference, even if just a small one, in each and every match. If you like FPS games, get it. If you don't, get it. If you want a hat simulator, get it. If you want a completionist's wet dream, get it. And best of all, of course, IT. IS. FREE.

game-hours: 714.3
review: This was my first game when starting Steam, and I loved every minute of it. It's free, it has an interesting community, and you can make money off of workshop items if they're implemented into the game! Let's actually start to go into detail here - If you bought the game back before 2007, then you won't have to go through what I'm gonna explain; Despite the game being free, there are some consequences that come with being what we call "Free-To-Play" or F2P for short. First off, you're gonna be treated like trash by some of the Premium-To-Play or Paid-To-Play players. You won't have a lot of luck in the Trade servers either unless you can trade. All you really have to be to become P2P(Paid/Premium-To-Play) is just buy anything from the Mann Co. Store, so that's a plus. Despite these inconviniences, the game is a hell of a time if you get past some of the bad parts of the community. For some people, this game might not be for you. That's fine, it's your opinion. But those of you who haven't tried the game already, I suggest trying it before casting your opinion into the sea known as Steam. My personal rating for the game is 8.9/10 for it being so damn fun.

game-hours: 377.3
review: Hat Simulator 2014 is a game about collecting hats, crafting hats, finding hats, unboxing hats, and trading hats. The game has a very complex algorithm for determining which hat you will find, based on choices you have made in the game. The game also includes minigames to play while you wait to recieve a hat, such as killing other players, pushing carts arounds, playing music over the mic, etc. I give this game an overall rating of 7.5 stars out of 2 thumbs up.
game-hours: 239.8
review: This game is totally wicked. Play it.
game-hours: 51.5
review: Team-based first person shooter with many gamemodes. TF2 convinces with solid gameplay and a strong focus on teamplay, watch each others back (literally... dat spy...), with clear roles given, you gotta know your place. Graphicly its ok, unfortunatly the german players are limited to low violence kiddy version for whatever reason (no matter how old the actual user is). The game should run on most machines, even if its 6 years old. The game modes are all enjoyable, and require different stragies of the teams. Gameplaywise the most annoying thing for beginners is probably getting killed by spies, until you start shooting everyone once in a while to make sure its really your team. The payment model is tricky though, first it seems very fair to play without paying anything, but then you realize that your backpack is way to limited to receive f2p-drops, and its hard to craft (+ limited receipes as non-premium). So getting the weapons you want is very unlikley. Unlike Dota 2 items which are cosmetic only, this items actually have stats and some change the way to play a class significantly. I recommend checking the game out if you are a fan of the genre, and then maybe spending <2$ to get premium status, that should give you enough drops and backpack space to enjoy the game for a longer time (until you decide if you want to spent more money, im not there yet). In the end its F2P, so just go for it. 'nuff said.

review: I've started playing this only recently, but I've known of it for a long time. I heard about it through G-Mod videos, but I didn't exactly know it was a game this awesome. I started a game and immediatly lost track of time. I swear, I was in that game for 15 minutes but the session time said 2 hours. Your life will go to this game, I promise. Huge pro is the fact you never really have to buy things with real money, unless you truly want to. Because, if you're lucky, you can find it for free in a round, which I think is perfect, and will keep me playing for a long time. I've only been playing for 5 days, and my small amount of hours is because I'm still in school, but I would HIGHLY recommend this to anybody that enjoys first person shooters or anything action. An amazing game with a huge fanbase, I love it.

game-hours: 304.8
review: I actually really enjoy playing this game, despite it being free to play. First piece of advice: Sell trading cards, until you have 10 cents, and then use it in the mann co store to buy a giftapault. After you do this, you have a premium account, can get hats, more drops, and more backpack slots. If you do this, you won't even need to spend any actual money on the game, since you don't NEED unusuals or taunts (But that doesn't keep them from being amazing), and you can pretty much get all the weapons anways, so this game really isn't pay 2 win at all, and I really like that about this compared to almost every other free to play title.

review: ap0o0
game-hours: 51.3
review: I had the game before it turned free to play, but it was worth the money! Saying this, if you haven't tried it, why not try it now, that it's completely free? You've nothing to loose! You have an infinite number os maps to play on, an infinite number of different weapons, nine classes and many game modes. If that doesn't cut it the game still has full integration with steam workshop! Team play is also important here. If you go rambo style, the probability is that you will end up dead sooner or later. Each character has it's own charisma and kind of "personality". You can find items while playing and use them to create your own weapons or to equip your characters. The graphics are good with some nice effects, nothing of the other world...but who cares? The fun to play this overcomes them by far. The options menu is well stashed, you have many, many settings to choose from, nothing is missing there, yet, is not confusing at all. The sounds of the weapons and general sound fx follow the fun theme of the game and the music themes are just hilarious! The gameplay is something you should be used to when playing Valve games, different from each game, but simple and awesome! Go for it! 9/10

game-hours: 112.6
review: hello, at first I didnt like it, I found graphics too childish, not pretty, I found the characters moving too fast, and the game too buggy, crashing all the time. Then I practiced a lot against bots. Then I got used to it, and I found my favorite class, first always played as heavy, now always pyro, maybe tomorrow another? Other things, it takes 14giga bytes on the hard disk, a lot, but modern games are like that, we are not int the era of 20 megas bytes games anymore...I find it sad, but pcs are faster too. Engine is based on half life 2, but game is buggy, for instance, when pressing ALT TAB, it takes forever to swap to desktop and to game again, sometimes crashes too. I had anoter problem : 2 GB RAM is NOT enough, you will need 3GB at least. Ok enjoy the game, and of course, this is not an intellectual game, it's about shooting and reflex, but you will need to be intelligent a little bit : learn the map, learn to anticipate ennemies movements, learn how to hide, to escape, learn to use weapons, learn where to go, when to go, etc This is not a simple play and shoot, this is more complex as it seems. And most important, it is a TEAMMMM game, that is if someone plays sh... then the team has problems, or if a doctor is mssing, who will heal you, if an engineer missing, who will build a sentry ? ... There is a lot to say, but I will stop here. Oh one note: I still find the characters are moving too fast for being "realistic" humans dont move that fast... Cheers.

Every class has their strengths and weaknesses, and teamwork for this reason is essential because every class can be countered by another class. game-hours: 172.7

game-hours: 390.6
review: It's an addictive multiplayer f2p hat simulator That's the first thing you should know...Hats are a status symbol a sign that you've sunk alot of money into the game (buying crates keys mostly) or have played for a long time next DO NOT WEAR THE GHASTLY GIBUS you will be hated for not being pay to play (stupid but true) gameplay is incredibly addictive and revolves around 9 classes (scout, pyro, soldier, demoman, heavy,engineer,sniper,medic and spy) all of which play very differently and uniquely the weapons you get that you can switch out the defaults for are ALMOST never straightly better then the defaults also you can get all of these weapons if your f2p Now this is a game with mod support so things like non official maps gamemodes and weapon mods exist and are very fun (but mostly not a fun as the main game) The different classes are all countered by another in some way shape or form and (as the name suggests) the game requires teamwork The scout is a harrassment class with a scattergun (a more close ranged based shotgun) a pistol and a baseball bat by default the pyro has a flamethrower woith a secondary fire that does an "airblast" that will reflect explosives and knock back players, a shotgun, and a fire axe the soldier has a rocket launcher with four rockets in it that CAN rocket jump, a shotgun, and a shovel the demoman has a grenade launcher, a stickybomb launcher (that is remote detonated) and a beer bottle the heavy has a minigun, an amazingly deep russian accent, a shotgun,and his baby man crushing fists the engineer has a shotgun, a pistol,a wrench, and two pdas which respectively build or destroy buildings you can create (the sentry gun, the dispenser, and a teleporter entrance and exit) all of which if you hit it with the wrench while it's building it will go faster. When it's fully built you can continue hittting it to upgrade it to a max of level 3, or heal it if it's damaged the sniper has a sniper rifle (you only get headshots while scoped in with it), an smg, and a kukri the medic has a needle gun, a medigun for healing that when you have filled up the "uber" meter you can secondary fire to make a player invincible for 10 seconds, and a bonesaw The spy has a revolver, a electric sapper for destroying buildings, a knife, and a disguise kit for making you look like a player on the enemy team. Also the spy's secondary fire will activate an invisibility watch that will drain as you use it The maps are blanced greatly. While their is no official respawn deathmatch mode however certain maps have been designated "TDM" unofficially due to the difficulty of achieving the objectives (plr_hightower) The gamemodes are usually varitions or just straight out cp or ctf gamemodes payload (pl) is where the attacking team mist push a cart of their color to the enemies base where it will explode and they will win the game capture point (cp) has two variations on it five cp and attack/defense cp both include caturing points (WOW) capture the flag is just that arena is a no respawn tdm gamemode king of the hill is a cp map wiht just 1 cpture point that the teams must attempt to hold for 3 minutes (the time left on the win timer stays after the point is recaptured by the other team) payload race is where their are two carts (one for each team) that's about it GET IT NOW IT'S FREEEE THE END

game-hours: 548.3
review: Team Fortress 2 (also known as Hat Fortress 2) is probably the best hat simulator on Steam. I reccomend it to anyone looking for a hat simulator. Its addictive quality, its cartoony art style and its great ammount of hats are really apealing and really give the game charm. I think graphics are the best part about games and Team Fortress 2 really shows off the Source Engine and how it can render hats with relative ease. The object of the game, as you probably know already, is to get as many hats as possible. You can get them by: A) playing a shooting minigame for about an hour a day to get a random hat drop (sometimes the random drops can be extra weapons to make the shooting minigame easier, I don't reccomend using them, though) B) Crafting your shooting minigame weapons into scrap metal to make a new hat eventually C) buying the hats off of the Mann Co. Store All in all, this is a great hat sim that I reccomend to everyone looking for a fun dressup game. I hope Valve makes more.

game-hours: 595.0
review: Getting a healthy amount of fun from shooters these days is...rather unlikely. One of the major FPS's known for doing that is Call of Duty. There's not much stratedgy involved, it's monotonous, and each installment might as well be just DLC. But Team Fortress 2 wants you to know that fun and innovation is possible to do in a FPS. There's 9 classes to choose from, each with there own characteristics and personalities, unlockables such as new weaponry and goofy (but cool to wear) hats, and the gameplay is so addicting that it's guaranteed to have you coming back for more. You'll be spending hours with people worldwide trying to capture/defend points, play a bloody game of capture the flag, or even maneuver a bomb-loaded minecart to force the RED team to call mercy. With so many rewards and achievements to unlock, as well as excellent co-op, it's no wonder that Team Fortress 2 has been known to be perhaps one of the best video games evr made. Just take caution when playing the Orange Box version on the XBox 360.

game-hours: 1143.0
review: My god where do I even start... EVERYONE on steam has heard of Team Fortress 2 at least once, and if they haven't they soon will. Highly addicting and loaded with tons of cartoonish fun and humor (and all the ing hats), TF2 is pretty much the face of steam (technically of Valve, but they're both made by them). The game itself is actually pretty challenging and is constantly changing. It's NOTHING like Call of Duty, where you can rely on just yourself to survive. In TF2, you actually have to work as a team to get anywhere, which I personally find great for a game. And every one of the 9 classes are unique, powerful, but still dependent on other classes. For example, you can't count on a whole team being snipers and expect to win (trust me, you wont. Ever.) You need variety and strategy. You need to work as a team in the fortress. 2. This game is free, but that doesn't say much. If you want to trade items (which are actually a huge part of TF2 thanks to hatcomony) then you either need to buy an item from the online store (lowest cost for an item is about 50 cents) or get a friend to get you premium. Now go out there and get on the point. Dummkopf.

game-hours: 382.7
review: Great Game to eat  while you .
game-hours: 1443.9
review: For the MORE educated people only! This game goes deep into the heart of economics where one could learn to trade various cosmetic items for metal. Each hat metapohrically represents a slice of life. The more hats you have, the more you are seen as a person in-game. The gibus, however, is like a dying stock share where one could never gain any sort of profit from it. A painted gibus is the ultimate display of poverty since it displays the well-proven fact that you no longer have a hat to paint! Therefore it is recommended that one takes every single STATS course in school in order to understand such a deep, and well-made hat simulator. I have lost my life investing into many hats in order to maximize my virtual metal income. I highly recommend this game for those who are interested in how microeconomics work. Also comes with a fps mini-game.

review: For about three years now, I've been a long-time collector of items in Team Fortress 2, trying to stay on top of new stuff when it comes out. And as frustratingly hard as that sometimes is, I wouldn't trade a minute of it for the world. I say that because Team Fortress 2 is genuinely one of the most fun experiences I've ever had with a video game, multiplayer or otherwise. I'm utterly terrible at most video games, but the fun I've had with TF2 makes me forget all of that, and just have fun with it. At its core, the game has a charm to me that's never even come close to dying out. I've met so many good friends and have so many accomplishments thanks to Team Fortress 2 that this one game has practically changed my entire life. And I'll love every minute of its past, present and future until the time the servers shut down; at which point, I will frame my collection as several large pictures, on each wall of my house, as a memento of time well spent.
game-hours: 7530.1
review: Team Fortress 2 (a.k.a. Trade Fortress 2, Hat Fortress 2, Promo Fortress 2, Team Fashionista 2, Team Freetress 2) is a class-based first-person hat collection simulator. Originally it was a faithful recreation of the original Quake and Half-Life mods, but has since evolved from its original design into a pointless virtual collect-a-thon where the player must collect every rare item they can by any means necessary, in order to inflate their ego and show off their E-peen. The original point of the game revolved around playing gamemodes, such as capturing the enemy intelligence, pushing a bomb to the enemy base, or controlling a whole map by Scout-rushing control points, although now all this became nothing more than a small minigame to pass the time with while you wait for more hats and as time went on, more weapons to magically drop into your inventory while doing  all on Achievement or Idle servers. 9.5/10 Overall 5/10 just for half the community being mann co store .

game-hours: 1955.2
review: People are giving reviews of this game, saying " BEST GAME 2013/2014". But these are not clear reviews at all. The reason why this game is fun, it is because it has unlimited replay value. When you step your foot into this game, and start to love this game. You're addicted. This game offers very unique mechanics, for example, the Soldier class can rocketjump into high places other classes may not be able to reach. Learning how to aim the rocket on your foot and propeling yourself up into the air can be very fun to play with. This game has a rather deep learning curve to certain classes, mostly being the Soldier, the Demoman, and the Spy. The Demoman is an interesting class to learn, he does not have any Hitscan weapons (weapons that do not have projectiles and hit immediately). He also has the ability to StickyJump, just like the soldier, but it costs more health, but brings you further and higher. Leaning how to do those Rocketjumps and Stickyjumps may not be an easy task to someone who is slower to the game. I took a year to learn how to rocket jump and complete a jump map easily. Different classes have different abilities, switch to the class that you are more comfortable with. But learning how to use more than 2 classes is important, you can switch classes if need be. This game offers a variety of weapons, each different for every class. Every weapon in the game is now balanced. And please, this game is not pay to win. You just have to pay 5 bucks to get premium status and trade your way up there. A weapon would not cost more than a dollar if you actually use the trading system wisely. The game also offers hats and miscs to wear for your favourite classes. There are people, called traders who trade their way so high up there, their backpack is worth a few hundred thousand dollars. If you're in into making a profit off a game that costs 5 dollars, and unlimited fun, this game is for you.

game-hours: 39.3
review: It is very rare to find a quality free-to-play game that's enjoyability does not diminish with play time. If you're reading this, you've found a prime example of such a game in Team Foretress Two. This multiplayer-centric, class based fps offers a wonderfully different and addictive experience for those burnt out on the typical first-person-shooter format. You can not run in solo, guns a blazin', and expect to do well in this game. You will have to choose from the nine classes offered and find which works best for you. All about destuction? A Heavy will loads of fun for you. Prefer to hang back and deal out death from a distance? Go Sniper. More of a healer than a fighter? Be a Medic and keep evrybody else going. None of these classes are invincible, however. A Heavy is a slow moving tank that will need constant support to stay alive, and and if you make one false move as a Spy, you'll get lit up. As the name suggests, teamwork is key here. You will need to find what play style and team startegy best compliments your prefered class. The equippent unlocks will also give you a reason to keep playing, as you hope to find that one piece of gear you really want. Get the basics and teamwork down, and you'll find yorself hooked, spending way too much time on this amazingly done, free-to-play title.
game-hours: 664.1
review: amazing never had more fun one of the best games ive ever played!
game-hours: 24.5
review: Team Fortress 2 offers a simple proposition: Throw a wall of humanity at a given objective and see what happens. The result is unimaginably entertaining and seemingly never gets old. The addition of item drops offer variety, but does not become a hinderance in the sense that you should feel the need to do 'homework' before jumping into a game. In fact, the ability to jump into a game is arguably TF2's greatest strength. Yes, there are classes with different abilities, and there are tutorials that will introduce you to the basics, but the game is simple enough to be able to learn by doing, and the frantic pace/ability to change classes between deaths will allow for quick experimentation to find your niche. Data on your performance with each class in loading screens are a nice way to recieve feedback if you're looking for it. Perhaps the best indicator of the emphasis on fun over compeition is the inclusion of kills but no deaths. There's really no way to tell if the guy sitting at 150 kills has it because they're god's gift to TF2 or because they've been playing for 6 hours straight, because there's no other frame of reference. This is a good thing because the goals of TF2 are immediate: Get the flag, push the cart, kill the guys wearing different clothing. The versatility of the format is also on display with the addition of a co-op mode: Mann vs. Machine. This, arguably, requires a bit more knowledge of the classes to successfully battle back a horde of robots, but also provides a new level of fun in the more tight knit group which is ideally composed of friends or agreeable strangers. With the inclusion of new items and holiday game modes, TF2 continues to be just as fun to play as it was the very first day you log in. Given the fact that it's free to play this really feels like a title someone should have tried at least once, and will continue to offer pure fun on afternoons where you simply can't make up your mind or have grown bored of other titles.

review: Team Fortress 2 An extemely addictive multiplayer Free-to-play FPS that pits two teams, (Red and Blu) aginst each other in objective based gamemodes ie. Capture the flag and Payload Race. There are nine classes to choose from, each giving a different experience to the player. With a multitude of weapons, you can customise a loadout that suits you and your style of play for an enjoyable round everytime. TF2 is a game that you can pick up and play whenever, for infinite replay value. And with a variety of community-made content, (gamemodes, maps, ect) there is always something new to experience. Also, there are hats.

review: You like HALO, Call of Duty, or anything in between? Then this game, ladies gentlemen, is for you. game-hours: 1306.5
review: TF2 is, to put it boldly, the most fun multiplayer FPS on Steam, and probably on PC. Call of Duty it isn't, and that's a good thing. Team Fortress 2 is a game where you choose from one of 9 different classes, all of which are expertly balanced and offer a playstyle for everybody, and try to complete an objective with your team. Teamwork is extremely important here, and those who just want to run around and do their own thing, trying to get as many kills as possible, won't last very long. Every class has a weakness that can be covered by another class, and when the right combination of players get together, magic can happen. There is no reason for you not to play this game, especially since it's free.

game-hours: 460.8
review: This game is great. Seriously. Even if you never played an FPS, you still need to play it. TF2 involves 2 teams (RED and BLU) trying to accomplish an objective. There are 9 classes to choose from, and they all play completely differently from each other. For example, the Scout is incredibly fast, but he has low HP. The Heavy is the opposite: he's the slowest class in the game, but he has a whopping 300 health. The classes counter each other nicely: are Spies backstabbing your team and easily taking down your defenses? Get some Pyros on your team to blast them away with their flamethrowers, getting rid of their disguises and invisibility. The game also has a lot of unlockable items. There are weapons that have slightly different stats than the orignals: for example, the Heavy's Brass Beast minigun does more damage than the stock minigun, but has a slower spin-up time and lowers your move speed more when spun up. There are also weapons that completely change how a class works: the Sniper's Huntsman replaces the sniper rifle with a bow that is best suited for medium-range fights. The game also has a TON of hats: these don't change any stats, but they make your classes look as swagtastic as possible. There's also a great trading system. The unoffical currencies of trading are scrap metal, crate keys, and earbuds: it's weird, but it's easy enough to get rich-ish. Overall, I'd recomend TF2 to anyone who likes video games. Also, it's free.

game-hours: 1650.6
review: A team-based (obviously) FPS that's as welcoming to first-timers as it is for seasoned vets. The various weapons available by achievements, drops, crafting and shop let you customize your class to how you want to play. And the various maps by Valve and the community gives you tons of options for places to play. Best enjoyed with friends. Now that this game is free you really have no excuse NOT to play it. It may seem intimidating to come in new when others have all kinds of newer weapons but don't let that keep you away! Stock weapons let you enjoy the game and in no way hinders your ability to have fun and assist your team. Plus since you get item drops anyway, you can still customize your classes with some of the other weapons so that your class plays the way that best suits you. If you want to get the benefits of a paid account just spend a buck in the MANN Co. store and you're in as good as those of us who paid for the game.

game-hours: 2341.8
review: Game: Team Fortress 2  Genre: FPS, Action, Hat-Wearing Simulator  Rating:      5/5  Favorable Aspects: Back in 2007, when it was released, not a lot of people had knowledge about this nowadays masterpiece, prefering to play games such as CS and it's mods. But what did TF2 have that none other game at the time could achieve? Well, we can point out many reasons, but I'll only detach two: game experience and simple gameplay. Combine a "cartoon" graphics FPS game with lots of classes, funny characters and objectives, then you'll get a different gamestyle everytime you join a match. I won't extend it because pratically every decent FPS gamer should've already played it or at least took a look, just ask around.  Negative Aspects: As every work has it's weak spots, it couldn't be different with TF2. To summarize: the addition of hats along with all the cosmetic items brought good and bad effects. The good (specially for Valve): you can customize your character outfit the way you like it, for a price of course. The bad is the unequal proportion between cosmetic and weapon updates, since they introduce a lot more cosmetic items than weapons. Besides, it was spent enough time to produce a new Team Fortress title.  How much is it worth to pay: [] Full Price* [ ] 75% [ ] 50% or Less *

review: 60's-70's action movie feeling? Sounds badass! An eye-catching exceptional graphical style resembling somewhat Pixar-esque? Fascinating. Lots of gratuituous ,graphical and humourous violence? Oh yes! Gameplay, which emphasises teamwork and is most fun when you man up with your mates - in addition giving a big middle finger for the opposing team by showing them how their collective effort sucks compared to your valuable, well-forged plan? HELL YEAH! It's Team Fortress 2! Even though it lacks the charm of grenades and insane leet tricks which you were able to perform in Team Fotress and TFC (my old love~), the TF2 works as a brilliant spiritual successor for its grandfather games I loved to play too. Get your hands on it - try it out, and see if you like it or not - for it's FREE!

game-hours: 2992.6
review: Very fun game, with a very fair f2p model. A very large community as well. Gameplay The game has nine different classes, each requiring different strategies to play. The use of specific items can change these strategy, adding more customization. Hats are fun too. Has a wide selection of game modes, with even more mods. Community There are many communities who run servers, and different people reside in different communities. Some communities, such as my favorite, Saxton Hell, have a very large diversity. There's a large modding community, large gaming community, and there's always a server out there. Difficulty Has a fairly steep skill curve, especially with more difficult classes. Some classes are easy to learn, however, such as soldier or heavy. Mann vs Machine A very different game mode compared to all the others. Weapons that were once situational or gimmicky become kings, and weapons that used to be amazing become useless. It's like a whole new game. There are some random kickers, however. Not as many as Left 4 Dead 2, luckily. Very fun game, strongly recommend. Very good f2p model, and VERY fun with friends.
game-hours: 269.6
review: Each class has their own play styles, and more can be learned from the other classes. For example, i used to suck as the spy. i didnt know the maps very well, and my skill with the revolver was non existant. After some time with the scout, i learned the maps better. Some more time, as the sniper, and I refined my aim. I am a decent spy now. Another strong point for the game is the weapons. While not upgrades, each weapon can change the enjoyment you get from one of the classes. Dont like how slow the heavy is? Put on the Gloves of Running Urgently. Want to heal during combat as the soldier? Meet the Black Box. Liking the demo but wanting to go medieval on someone? give him a sword and sheid and unleash the DemoKnight.

review: Team Fortress 2, a masterpiece in online entertainment. What I like most is there's no pressure, few flamers, and a laid back environment to shoot people. There is no better bonding between friends that hitting a Heavy with a baseball bat. Guaranteed fun, but if your computer is slow, the game will be practically impossible to play. Need quick reaction, and a steady mouse. What's more... it's FREE!

game-hours: 1725.6
review: Killed a minigun-wielding Russian with a fish. 10/10
game-hours: 1422.2
review: This game is unfathomably good. I don't even like first-person shooters, and not only do I still like TF2, it's actively my favourite game of all time. There are 9 classes, each with different playstyles, and each with a bunch of different weapons you can use to fine-tune the class to how you want to play. It's impressive how balanced the game is - each weapon has benefits and drawbacks compared to the stock weapons you have when you first start the game. There are a few whose benefits outweigh the drawbacks and vice-versa, and a couple that are literally direct upgrades, but you never feel like you're at a huge disadvantage by not having certain weapons. The fact that the game's around 7 years old and they're still updating it is incredible. The Mann vs. Machine update added a new game mode that's a sort of tower defence game. It could have been its own $20-$30 game, but nope, Valve gave it to everyone for free. There are some advantages premium players have over free players, but none of them directly affect gameplay - Premium players can keep more items and trade. Trading makes it so easy to get weapons and Premium can cost less than a dollar, so I really don't see any reason to not upgrade yourself to Premium. I guess at some point I have to talk about hats. They seem silly, right? Why bother making so much of the content have no effect on gameplay? But that's exactly why they do it! A new weapon isn't just about modelling and scripting. You have to make sure it's balanced and can't be exploited in any way. But hats and other cosmetic items can't possibly be 'unbalanced', so of course they can add a hundred hats easier than they can add one new weapon. Maybe they could focus more on weapons, but there are already so many as it is; you don't want to make it impossible for new players to catch up. So obviously TF2 is amazing. 10/10 would play again and probably will this afternoon. There are, however, a few drawbacks. TF2's normal devotion to balance makes it all the more glaring when something isn't balanced. The Soldier has so much versatility in his weapons that it's pretty easy to call him /the best class/ in a game that's supposed to be about teamwork. It's pretty easy to see Valve playing favourites with the Soldier. If some class has a weapon that players are favouring over the other options, most of the time Valve will nerf the over-used weapon (ex. the Spy's Dead Ringer). But for the Soldier, they'll just buff the under-used weapons (ex. The Concheror and Battalion's Backup). Giving the Soldier extra upgrades in Mann vs. Machine also reeked of favouritism when it's the Spy and Pyro who needed the help. One other drawback is that the store's prices on weapons has absolutely nothing to do with how rare / common they are. This isn't really Valve's fault, but it makes a lot of things in the store complete rip-offs. Suppose you want a Phlogistinator. It costs $10 in the store. OR you could buy four Keys ($2.50 each). Each key is worth, in the trading economy, about 100 Phlogistinators. I'm not exaggerating. (Phlogistinator: 0.05 - 0.11 refined. Key: about 8.66 refined.) Basically, once you know a little bit about the economy, you feel like you have to REALLY get into it so you don't get ripped off. Or maybe that was just me.
game-hours: 792.7
review: The game is fun. The community is normally SO much better than that of Cod's or BFF's. The micro-transactions are good too. You can get almost anything from item drops in-game. And there are so many different gamemodes! You have the default ones, Doomsday, CTF, CP, but then you have community made ones (that I think some should be real ones,) Freak Fortress 2, Arena, X10, all very fun! It's also very easy to record, as you can easily set up events, give yourself a challenge, or simply shoot at things! All the classes are very different as well, and can help eachother on the same team, (Medic + Heavy) or can destroy eachother on the opposing team, (Sniper + Spy or Spy + Pyro.) Anyways, I recomend this game to everyone, even if you dislike FPS games, because to be honest, this game will never be normal. It's to late to go back.

game-hours: 101.2
review: For a free to play game, this is almost perfect. First of all, it can run on my terrible computer, so we're off to a good start. Second, it's free. I'm usually low on funds, so that's awesome. Third, there's tons of items EVERYWHERE. With the variety, it's almost impossible to not find a working combination to use. And don't complain that you have to pay for items, because you don't. If you play in random boot camp servers all day, you are guaranteed at least ten free items. Granted, they could all be the same thing, but that's what community market is for. Forth, and most overlooked, there is an offline practice with bots mode. I have a laptop, and my internet is terrible (I call it NL for negative latency). This mode ensures I can at least play PvP mode. Five, for the most part, the community doesn't suck like other communities *cough* call of duty *cough*. Sixth, Valve is always updating it with new content. And lastly, this is the best hat simulator you will ever play. EVER. NO EXCEPTIONS. ALL OTHER HAT SIMULATORS WILL BE LABELED AS POSERS. My one concern (or complaint) is that several of the Ghost Town servers have map rotation on. You do NOT do that to people. Ghost Town is not a normal MvM map. If people choose the Ghost Town server, they should have a dedicated Ghost Town server. If I wanted to play another map, I would have chosen another map. Since most of the MvM Ghost Town servers aren't directly managed by Valve, I can't hold it against them. But we seriously do need more Ghost Town dedicated servers. 10/10 Would visit Pyroland again.

review: PC Gamer called it "the most fun you can have online!" That's probably the most accurate review there is. No game is perfect, but Team Fortress 2 isn't far from it. I wholeheartedly recommend this masterpiece to any gamer worth his/her salt.

game-hours: 408.9
review: You know those games that no one will shut the  up about, well that was how i thought of team fortress 2, as another bland fps to add to the collection, but jumping into this game led to more then i could ever want from a game. Hilarious charecters and weapons, yet this stupidly funny game also has some of the most solid and complex gameplay ive seen come out of a fps. With unique weapons and strategies to each of TF2's nine classes, this game is sure to keep ANYONE intertained no matter what your favorite playstyle is, like being sneaky?, use the spy. like support classes?, try the medic or engineer.Like going in  rambo killing everything?, choose the pyro,heavy or soldier. by the way, there actually isnt a single class that's bad, the game is beautifuly balanced in that department, no class feels better then the other they all are the best in certain situations. Oh, and how could anyone forget the RIDICULOUS personalities of the classes, whereever its the balls to walls insanity of the soldier, the obnoxiousness of the soldier or the laid back sorta, gentle nature of the engineer. Now the weapons, MY GOD ARE THERE SO MANY WEAPONES, like jeasus christ, you can make a pokemon game out of these weapons, to not waste time i wont explain the weapons cause that will just be like writing the bible in a steam review. to wrap it up in a nice pumpkin spiced scented bow this game is free and money is only needed to buy the weapons (if you are too lazy to find them) and hats, if you want a game with enough hats to fill country then this game will snuggle nicley with you. while not having any buffs, there is something satisfying about dressing the spy as doctor who or the medic as a captain. This game is heavly multiplayer and will supply endless hours of fun with its humor, great gameplay and a whole stockpile of content this game is well worth the download but remember, spys are everywhere.

review: Team Fortress 2 (TF2) is the sequel to the game that put class-based, multiplayer team warfare on the map. TF2 delivers new gametypes, a signature art style powered by Valves next generation animation technology, persistent player statistics, and more. Unlike other "class-based" games that offer a variety of combat classes only, Team Fortress 2 packs a wild variety of classes which provide a broad range of tactical abilities and personalities, and lend themselves to a variety of player skills. Play as the flame-throwing Pyro, the room clearing Heavy, or the Spy, a master of disguises. Other classes include: Scout, Sniper, Medic, Engineer, Demoman, or Soldier. TF2 features the most advanced graphics of any Source-based game released to date  and the most exciting class-based action ever created. [Valve]

game-hours: 1236.6
review: Simply put, one of the greatest competitive multiplayer games ever created. Having played almost everything in the online FPS genre from the classics to the modern hits, Team Fortress 2 is the single game of the bunch that has kept me entertained years later; six years and counting thus far. The look and feel to the game and its characters ooze charm and personality. The plethora of different looks and loadouts keep the game fresh, with more new things coming out all the time. The gameplay itself is easy enough to pick up for immediate gratification, yet deep enough where it can take hundreds, if not thousands of hours to master any given playstyle. Whether you just put in spare time over a weekend, or dedicate several hours every day, TF2 has a way of making you feel constantly satisfied and rewarded as the years go by. Having adopted an extremely fair free-to-play business model now, there's no reason to not give it a go.

game-hours: 157.1
review: *WARNING SEREVERE SPELLING/TYPING MISTAKES INSIDE* I have waited long enough to write a review of this game, today is the day as i am bored out of my mind. To start off, this is a first person shooter game which succesfully grabs hold of a player and drags them away to a colourful and eccentric world where two companies/corparations fight each other endlessley with 9 specially selected mercanaries. The scout, The soldier, The pyro, The Demoman, The Heavy, The Engineer, The Sniper, The Medic and The Spy. All of these classes have their strenghths and weaknesses, such as lets say the sniper, he can very easily get 1 hit kill via headshots but as he is a camping unit he is especially weak to the spy's 1 hit kill backstab (unless you have the razorback which will more likely kill the spy) but then that spy is sucestible to the pyro's flames as he can "Spy Check" his team. This series has been so popular it has sprung a massive community of gamers, designers or even gamers who design the wepons themselves, it's even got itself a healthy succesful De-Make, Gang Garrison 1 & 2, this really does show how this game has become a pillar of valve's fans as it is a free to play game but with many in-game purchasing options. This brings to one the only things i have against this game. Those Danm Mann Co Crates. They are very good if you have the money to spend on keys but if you don't, well it clogs up valuable backpack space and basiclly prompts you to trash or buy a key to open the item. But all in all his is a great game beautifully made in a cartoonish bloody war type of fashion. I'd Recommend it to most players who have access to steam or the gearbox ill give it 0.8 out of 1 (as /10 is overused).

review: This game is amazing. I just wanted to get that out there to begin with, but now I will tell you why. Finally there is a good community, with user submiited content which gives fans a way to give back to the community, and the facinating TF2 econmomy which is constantly shifting based off active user imput the game has a life and viatality that sets it aside to many other games I have played. On the whole I would rate TF2 5/5 stars, I truely belive that this game has so many amazing elements that are done right and I have no desire to stop playing anytime soon.

game-hours: 246.0
review: Team Fortress 2 is one heck of an FPS. This game has no campaign mode, no in-game information regarding the story, or anything along these lines. However, it doesn't need these elements. The multiplayer is the only thing it needs, and it excels at this. TF2 offers an extraordinary amount of diversity. The most obvious of which are the nine classes. Each class requires an incredibly different playstyle than any other, all being unique with their own roles to play. The Scout can run around and distract opponents, while the Heavy tanks hits like no other. For this reason, the need for a team becomes obvious. Each class has distinct weaknesses that can be covered by the other classes. Thus the name, TEAM Fortress 2. However, there's more than just the nine classes to add to the diversity. Each class also has a slew of weapons that, while functioning similar, have enough of a difference to each that they can completely change the way you play a class. For example, the Direct Hit rocket launcher of the Soldier punishes the usual tactic of using the splash damage of the rocket in exchange for a powerful hit when connecting with the opponent. Each class has quite a few options with how they can play. TF2's reliance on your team makes each game play differently. Being on a heavily offensive team is much different than being on a team full of Engineers or Demomen. This requires the player to adapt and constantly need to adjust to fill any holes on the team. This is not a game where you can just fight individually and expect to succeed. This involves far more strategy and thought than the gameplay would initially have you believe. Speaking of the gameplay, it is simply fantastic. The controls are smooth, logical, and can fit any level of desired precision. There is, on a full server, a constant level of action from spawn up until death, and there's never a boring moment. TF2 is a game that must be experienced to understand just how excellent it is. This game is addicting, and never becomes dull like other FPS games. Since it is now free, there is no reason to not at least give it a try.
game-hours: 2190.5
review: A review for a 7 year old game is not something i would usually write. But i figure after playing 1500+hrs of this game its time to actually give a fair review of this. Where to start? Well Team Fortress 2 (or TF2 everywhere else) is a humorous FPS game made by the wizards at the huge gaming company Valve (who made the very platform you're reading this review on). It involves the "story" of two teams (R.E.D. and B.L.U or Reliable Excavation Demolition and Builders League United) of their control over wastelands, gravel pits and dustbowls. The teams are made up of 9 playable types of Mercenaries or Classes which include the Scout, Soldier, Pyro, Demoman, Heavy, Medic, Sniper, Engineer and Spy. Each class has their own set of unique abilities skills which players can master including the Scout's double jump, Demoman and Soldier's ability to jump through the air with their own explosives (known as Sticky/Rocket Jumping) and the Spy's ability to disguise as other members of the enemy team in order to trick them into thinking they're friendly and then subsequentely backstab with his trusty them for an instant kill (a painful way to go i might add). Each class has its own purpose and function which at some points can prove to be crucial to winning games. The game modes themselves include a simple Capture the Flag mode in which one team must protect their own intelligence while trying to capture the other teams intelligence, a King of the Hill mode, a payload mode in which you must push a cart all the way through various checkpoints while the other team tries to stop you and many other modes as well. There even includes a mode called Mann Vs Machine in which waves of robots try to deliver a bomb to a point which you are trying everything you can to protect it which includes having to use upgradable abilities for each class which enables you to do huge amounts of damage to the robots themselves. There exists Halloween Modes with which you do battle with ultra powerful (if not obnoxious) wizards, giant flying eyeballs and a Horseless Headless Horsemann which can decapitate you instantly (Valve normally add a new boss every halloween as well so you never know what to expect). As with most First Person Shooters you have the capability to customize your classes, but the sheer amount of items you can customize your class with is unbelievable, from new weapons (which include killstreak weapons that count how many kills you get in a single life and stranges which count how many kills you get with that weapon), hats (which can include ultra rare Unusuals) and jackets, shoes and other humourous accessories such as teddy bears, voodoo dolls and so much more. There is so much content in this game you can find i cant even put it into words. So performance of this game? Well depending on what sort of pc you have (i have a decent laptop with which to play on) the game can run smoothly in places and badly in others (you may have to fiddle with settings a bit to find the best performance). But that doesn't mean this game is badly connected, in fact its very solid throughout after playing two years of it. As you can see as well, this game is Free to Play (forever) but you may have to consider spending a bit of money at least in order to access the full features of the game (such as crafting more things, having a bigger backpack and getting better item drops) but by all means you can play for free, its just that you cant access everything this game has to offer which can sometimes alienate players. The community for this game is fairly friendly (with the occasional player taking it too seriously) but i find you just ignore these kind of players you will always have fun with this game (That's what games are for right?) There is also a strong trading community within this game, with community made maps just for trading on and the trading is endless with this game (but always be aware of scammers, they exist, just keep on your toes). There is a competitive base for this game as well, with many tournaments and lobbies that exist for this game (and trust me, they're good players). And although this game can get frustrating at times, when you lose at the last hurdle or get dominated by someone multiple times, it immeadiately evens it up with satisfactory revenges and even winning games. Just keep a mind on the time because you're likely to spend a lot of it playing this game. So overall this game has endless content (even at Free 2 Play level I must say) a good variety of modes and challenge, smooth performance and an eye catching art style which is sure to grab any gamers attention. For free? This game is an absolute must have. Scores: Originality: 9/10 Fun: 9/10 Challenge: 10/10 Variety: 9/10 Performance:9/10 Overall: 9.5/10

game-hours: 293.8
review: Call of Duty: Modern Warfare has a cousin named Team Fortress 2. They're both from the FPS family. Except CoD was always the popular jock in town, and always had the looks, the brawns and the money. Team Fortress 2 on the other hand is that guy you wanna be friends with, get drunk with, party with, and/or cause a riot in town with. It's that FPS family member that you can always count on to not take business too seriously, and have fun with it. Team Fortress 2 has that cartoonish style, flair, and hilarity to it that even the most popular FPS games cannot compare to. And guess what? It's free. So grab your guns, your melee weapons, and your friends cause it's gonna be one hell of a ride with Team Fortress 2. Download and enjoy whenever you can.

game-hours: 89.0
review: awesome
game-hours: 1185.2
review: I'll be honest here: I don't like First Person Shooters. It feels like 99% of them have dull graphics, uninteresting Michael-Bay-esque plots and vapid gameplay. When I first started up Team Fortress 2 I didn't expect much, given my past experiences with the likes of Call of Duty, Halo, Battlefield, etc. (which all bored me in about two minutes). Team Fortress 2, however, feels dynamic and refreshing. There are nine different classes. From the Soldier to the Medic, to the Engineer and the Spy, they all offer a unique style of gameplay, so it's likely you will find at least one that you have fun playing as. The characters that each represent a class all have quirky personalities and humourous lines, and I have come to love every one of them. I think everyone who has played TF2 has their favourite character. Teamwork is a big focus in this game and it's the key to victory. You can't roam around killing people on your own like in CoD because each class has their weaknesses that they rely on other classes to help mitigate. Deathmatch and Free-for-All aren't even game modes; all game modes involve completing an objective, so if you aren't willing to contribute to a group effort, you are doomed to face defeat over and over and it's as simple as that. This is a very positive gameplay trait and promotes a somewhat more friendlier and social experience. The likes of Call of Duty and Battlefield aren't nearly as co-operative as Team Fortress 2. Team Fortress 2 is easily my favourite FPS I've ever played. If you haven't tried it yet, I highly recommend you do. There's bound to be something you will love about it.

This game is amazing and if you have Steam and don't have this game Get It cause you'lll be missing on all the Shooting, Burning, Sniping Exploding, Backstabbing and Sanvich eating mayhem.

review: TF2 was the first game I played on steam and It is my favorite besides TorchLight and Terraria. I wouldn't recommend this game to kids younger than 12 because it does contain some mature content with strong violence. Even though it is only for 18 and up it does have some content that is humorous and occasionally comical to middle schoolers and people younger than 18. In videos for the playable classes most strong course language is bleeped out. The game play is simple, you play to achieve your teams objective which may be to capture a control point or capture their intel. In most cases the other team is trying to do the same and stop you from doing so, which is where part of the strong violence comes in. The other part of the strong violence is for the many ways you can kill your enemys ,rockets, flame-throwers, automatic guns and remote detonatable bombs. Part of the humer may be the classes back grounds and how they act. If TF2 is not the ideal game for you there are other games with almost the same game play of TF2 such as Ace of Spades. In conclusion TF2 will provide addictive game play for days ( and yes ) nights to come.

review: If you like hats, get this game. I for one love hats, and this is what this game is about. Hats. If a team has 4 spies and 3 snipers, you will falter and fail and have to hear the others complain about how you are a noob. Do not listen to them, you can be the change you need. Simply choose a class that can alter the playing field. Teams is full of heavies? Spies and snipers, sure. But what about demomen and soldiers? Try pyros and heavies. Annoyed that you are stuck in a crucial area of the map? One or two medics with ber and all is forgotten. It is a simple process of rock, paper, scissors and you simply have to see what the other person's hand is and change accordingly. If you remain a rock, people will plaster you with paper.

game-hours: 329.2
review: The community for this game is pretty great. Most of the people on here are willing to teach you how to play any of the classes and make recommendations on which weapons to use, play style, etc. It's really easy to change the key layout so you can use a gamepad or other controllers. Matches are pretty short too, which means you can come home and play a quick game rather than having to devote an entire day to the game. There are also plenty of weapon drops, so you don't absolutely need to buy upgrades to have a chance to play better. Overall, pretty great game!

review: PLAY IT. (*fine*) You are one of nine mercenaries, the Scout, the Pyro, the Soldier, the Engineer, the Heavy, the Medic, the Spy, the Sniper or the Demoman, and your job is to load enemies with lead. Several gamemodes, with new ones being added every once in a while, all of them fun. Do you like popping lead into everything? Then you're a Heavy. Do you like run 'n' gun gameplay? Then you're a Scout. Do you like destroying your enemies $#!* with grenade launchers and sticky bombs? Then you get to be a Demoman. Each character has a visual personality, and there's a character for eveyone. I don't play this game as much as I wish I did, but still, I highly reccomend it. :)

review: This game is AMAZING, here are a few reasons why: 9 different classes with very different skills and weapons, these weapons can and will match almost everybody's playstyle. tf2 is a multiplayer game this is great because the experience will be new each and everytime. There is a very minor setback which is that without wifi it isn't very fun to play...but who doesn't have wifi?? lots of different game modes and an abundant number of maps for each game mode there is a HUGE tf2 comunity, there's hardly gonna be a time when you search for a game and there isn't anybody playing in them, not to mention that the tf2 comunity is awesome :D very helpful and nice MOST of the time with a few acceptions Hats... do I need to say anymore? Yes... I do... there are a BUNCH of hats, accesories, pins, badges, and, well... hats. But seriously, the amount of hats in TF2 are off the charts. with this come the unusuals and paints and rare items...and with THESE come scammers... there are those consumed in wanting rare hats that they'd do nearly anything with it... but this can't be helped. with the random drop system, tf2 makes it so that with enough time playing, you WILL get that weapon you've always wanted...or you could just borrow from the store. Speaking of the store... you never wanna buy from the store, it's usualyy not worth your money. But being a premium member (which requires you to buy from the store) you can trade items, and this is where you should get those weapons, or... make a profit. there are a TON of content creators for tf2 with a bunch of new accesories and things coming from this There's ROCKET JUMPING... 10/10 valve, you've done a GREAT job.... Just don't forget about Team Fortress 3... eagerly awaiting
game-hours: 780.7
review: After 383.1 hours of actual gameplay, I can officially say that TF2 is one of the best games ever made -You only need to play for 1 hour to realise that... So much variety is in this game in terms of playstyle, game modes and funnies that your experience is only tempered by your imagination. I've abstained and returned so many times and it still holds appeal: something that other games have never achieved. It's a good laugh with friends or solo but don't take it too seriously. TF2 is far from a serious game and should be played with a grain of salt. For those of you looking for a challenge, you'll find it if you look for it. If you believe the notion that this game takes little skill to master due to the presence of laser and rockets, you couldn't be more mistaken. It's free as well; don't knock it till you've tried it. 10/10 would hat again

game-hours: 2162.3
review: Yeah... it's about that time I finally review this big heaping pile of a game. But how do you review or describe an mmo? Especially one like this? Team Fortress 2, if you already don't know by the time you are reading this, is a mmofps, that unlike most in the genre; sticks out entirely. 9 classes, each with special weapons/abilities. The best thing, is that this not only makes them vulnerable to other classes, but able to counter them as well. Making it so that there is no class better than the other, the skill level on each class depends on how comfortable and used to the class you get. Aside from having a vast amount of weapons available, there are also hats and miscs so that you can style up your classes however way you want. So you can finally play through your fantasy of a scottish samurai battling an american shogun. Score: 9/10 - Truly, admittedly there has been times where I can really hate this game, but at the end of the day, I'll always be booting it up over and over again. Plus, it's a Free to Play game, so whats stopping you from at least giving it a try? Replay Value: High - Even after giving up on the game twice and going on several hiatus's, I always find myself coming back after game changing updates happen, or new content is added each halloween and such.

game-hours: 502.1
review: Team Fortress 2 commonly known as "TF2" is a Free to play First Person Shooter Multiplayer game. Team Fortress 2 is based around 9 playable classes each with a unique playstyle. Whether you want to run up to someone burning them alive with a flamethrower or stay in the back sniping people's heads off or even building a sentry gun as a defence unit or healing your teammates as a support unit, there is a wide variety of classes you are certain to find one for your playstyle. Team Fortress 2 also very balanced and even a new player has a chance to save the team from a loss. Which also leads to being a lone wolf often leads to a bad team. Even a Spy which is based around assassinated people from the behind need to help out the team by weakening the enemy team's defences. Team Fortress 2 also has a very good economy and is very often used in the Team Fortress 2 community. Unfortunately Free to play are not allowed to trade. Its worth it and players who play real life money on the game don't really get an advantage over Free to play other than they get nice looking cosmetics such as hats. The cheapest thing in the store at the moment is $0.10 in the online store which will make you a Premium. Another Flaw is that People who don't like multiplayer should NOT play this game due to it's Team based gameplay and no single player story. The closest you can get to playing by yourself it playing the Tutorial or playing offline practice. Other than that If you want a good game to play with your friends or just out of pure bordom, I would highly suggest this game. Do it for the Hats

review: This game is extremely well made, a damn fine example of how in depth you can go with a class-based FPS. TF2 dabbles in a little bit of everything; besides the base game, you can also find a range of community servers that offer unique experiences, and also about 1.4 billion Minecraft Trade Servers. But the great thing about this game is its personality. The classes aren't just faceless people who generically fit their role, each class has a personality and a backstory, given in the impressive amount of TF2 lore through comics and videos. The F2P aspect means you're able to try the game, and if isnt for you, just quit it, you havent lost a single thing. The claims that this is the best F2P game out there. If I had to note a problem with this game, it's my addiction to it, and the fact that it's cost me well over 100 dollars at this point from in-store purchases to get into the in-game market 10/10 God damn, I don't know what else I would give a game I've wasted over 1,700 hours of my life in.

review: yes
game-hours: 6012.4
review: Ok, I'm very close to 6k on this game. So I'll make a review ^^ This game is insanely fun, and not only if it fun but it's hilarious and still can be competitive. I find this game so hilarious, every couple of minutes on a pub you'll hear yourself saying "How the hell did that sentry get there" It's got a huge competitive side still imo, and competitive is very fun if you want a challenege, a lot of teamwork involved. Better then games where nobody cares what anybody else does. So many fun classes to choose from, you can play heavy and roll up the minigun and mow down scouts, or you can play pyro and defeat the spy class and reflect rockets into the very soldier that shot it at you (reflect with m2 on your mouse) The amount of stupid ragdolls and hilarious things you can do is pheonomenal, playing tons of different gamemodes. From saxton hale where you can sprint around as a god mode Australian guy and one shot everybody, or you can play MvM with your school buddies and get awesome rare items from the drops at the end. Then there are tons of halloween and christmas updates/maps and gamemodes. The game updates a ton but not too much to be annoying, and every update adds a bunch of new items and fun things to do. And this game is very well rounded, each class has an exact counter to it so nothing it ever too powerful (depending on what skill level the opponent is at) And pretty much all weapons have downsides which don't make it op, and it always has a counter. There are some exceptions like the phlogistanator, or the pompson but these two have their downsides even if their up sides are a bit over the top. But be warned, if you go into a pub be ready to verse people way better then you, if so. Just leave and change server or join the good players team and heal him with a medigun to gain tons of points :) Also pretty much all the people on servers and competitive are nice, obviously every single game has ***holes, but it gets balanced by so many lighthearted, funny, and helpful people. Make sure you try out every gamemode and different types of mods before you shut this game down from your life. Hopefully I convinced some people to play this game, and as I said I have nearly 6k on this game and I'm not even close to bored of it. Just don't be a horrible person and I can guarantee you'll enjoy this game if you put some effort into it. And I reckon a good tip is to not try and start of being really good at this game. Just enjoy it and mess around doing random stuff, and you'll get good at the game normally. Tris~
