There are very interesting weapon choices as well -they are not all guns! The weaponry can range from a heavy machine gun to a little mackarel fish that you can slap people around to death. It adds a whole nother realm of whimsical fun and to some points, some good old wackiness. The taunts are -oh my goodness- hilarious. There are many different kinds of taunts you can use with each character, which further adds to a completely unique gameplay depending whether or not you're willing to spend a good couple of bucks, which can be the downside of this game since the items can be quite top dollar expensive. One thing I appreciate from Valve the most out of this game is that you can turn off the blood -now even your kids can play this game! Ingenious. If you like shooting games, definitely try this out! game-hours: 824.4
review: I fell in love with the game since it's release at 2007. Just by watching the updates of the characters, the comics and "Meet the..." videos they occationaly released. And when i finally got to play it at january of this year. It was one of the greatest experiences of my life. The game i coveted since 6 years ago was finally at my grasp. And even after i was a n00b i pwned. It was the first online game were i actually pwned. Me and Pyro burning every team to the defeat with a simple Stock Flamethrower... It was a warm welcome. It has its ups and downs. Like ANY game. Even TLOZ OoT had it's flaws and it's still considered one of the top notch games ever. What i'm trying to say is, putting aside the F2P Rat Boys, the unbalanced weps, trolls, monetary scams, crates, glitches, mic spammers and about 404 rage quits before never saying Pootis again. It's the best game of our online generation. Why? It's one of the few games where the developers ACTUALLY hear the comunity, they also encourage them to make their own content. Just for having fun or to even put it in the shop so their effort gets some profit. Lots of custom servers. Enjoyable, unique and lovable characters and backstories. A unique gameplay and a lot of great humor. They also made it F2P. I'm pretty sure most of you guys that bought the game will hit me with rocks for saying that F2P is a possitive thing. You may think they just did that to keep the game alive. AND thats pretty much the reason they did. But look it at the bright side. The community expanded, there were more people to play, more chances and a lot of n00bs to pwn. Anyway thats just my opinion. Thanks, Valve.

After getting this game in 2012 I can finally give it a full-on review, for I've logged in 1000+ hours, yippee. +Unique characters have unique characteristics - each are unique in their own way. +Cool soundtrack - needs in-game music! +Complex weapon system - each has their own pros and cons. +Many gamemodes to choose from - Payload was a really nice one! +Fair item drop system - play the game to get items, no farming! +Many cosmetics - the game is all about hats now. +Gives off a fresh starting feeling - basically, newbies are thrusted into a cool environment. +One of the many great games from the 2000s (Excluding 2010+) +Great name - can't help it. +Great sound effects - Beep beep boop. +Good voice acting and communications system! +Community-made gamemodes - SAXTON HAAAAAAAALE! +/- Received a lot of updates - it has lost its nostalgic feeling for me. :( +/-The community of players - varies in good and bad ways. +/-The fanbases that are absorbed into the game - Bronies, otakus, etc. -No in-game music playing during game - menu songs are amazing! D: -Has lost its nostalgic feeling - this goes for many of the games I play, too many hats and updates! Overall, I played this game a lot, I've seen its community progress. I feel bad that TF2 has lost half of its community this year because of CS:GO, with all of the veteran players switching to the latter. Oh well, I hope the future of this game will still be bright! As for my rating: 83% "I'm gunna steeck mey thumbs in yer eyeballs and hang on 'till ye dead!" I had a good run overall, but now I've moved on to other stuff. So, I can conclude by saying - Thank you, Team Fortress 2.

game-hours: 571.7
review: If you don't have it, why are you on Steam?
game-hours: 808.1
review: At first this game may just seem like a not serious, cartoony mess. But if you actually download and play it for a while, youll start to realize how much there is to this game. TF2 really isnt like any other fps you find out there. May it be Battlefield, Call of Duty or Counterstrike. There are 9 different classes to choose from here (Scout, Soldier, Pyro, Demoman, Heavy, Engineer, Medic, Sniper and Spy), each one with completely different weapons and playstyles. Yes, even W+M1 is a playstyle (youll start to figure out this part if you play the game). The Scout has high mobility due to his runspeed of 133% and ability of doing doublejumps, can dish out high damage really quickly (if played correctly) but doesnt have a lot of health. The Spy can disguise as enemy players and get a one-hit-kill with his backstab if they arent paying attention (or the pings of the other players are in their favour). His revolver is very powerful if aimed right and works just fine if you missed your backstab. The engineer can build 3 different buildings: The sentry gun, which is a very strong aimbot turret; the dispenser which gives health and ammunition to teammates, and the teleporter which, as you could imagine, teleports teammates from one place to another. His biggest concerns are spies (who can sap his buildings), demomen (who can blow up his buildings), and medics (who can charge the so called "ber", that gives 10 seconds of invulnerability to him and whoever he's healing). But if your teammates are helping you and you can aim somewhat well, these classes wont be to much of a problem. The last point is about the f2p-model and the leveling. In Tf2, every single weapon has a downside and an upside (actually: there are a few weapons which dont have any stats and there are some weapons which have one minor upside). There arent any direct upgrades to weapons, like in call of duty (or 65% of all first person shooters for that matter). The only bonus that a player who has played longer than a beginner have is experience. So there arent any "booster packs" for real money or stuff like that. "Well then how does valve make money with this game????" you might ask. Yeah, there are crates that contain cosmetics. One key to open one crate is 1,89 euros (STOP RIGHT THERE: as of april 2015, one key costs 2,29 euros. WTF VALVE). And that is how valve makes money off of the players. So, after this freaking long review, you better download Team Fortress 2 right now, or ill be using minisentries. bye

review: Team Fortress 2 is an excellent all-rounder objective based fps game featuring different characters that counter each other which really requires teamwork if skill levels are balanced on both teams. Team Fortress 2 also is considered as a "casual" game to many gamers bent on setting an image for themselves. Team Fortress 2 is both fast paced or pure strategy based depending on how serious you'd play the game. If you ever do get bored of Valve's standard maps, different unofficial maps and gamemodes do exist within the server search menu. Overall Team fortress 2 is fun and easy to get into since the classes are designed to be simple. it just takes a little getting used to and you're good to go.

game-hours: 82.9
review: Game Grade: A- Explanation for rating: Team Fortress 2, or TF2, is a wonderfully comical first person shooter. The game does not focus on graphics or realism by any means (unless beating down your foes with a lollypop is normal for you). TF2 is quite enjoyable from a comical standpoint which is outstandingly hilarious. Something else you can enjoy in the game is the balanced game play (will be addressed later in the review). The replay value of TF2 is rather high due to the countless modded servers and new equipment you can unlock. The game is very fun and you can rest knowing that the download time was well worth it (seeing its a free game the only thing spent is time). Team Fortress has a very unique and comical first person shooter aspect to it. The fighting in the game is all based off of comedy. Weapons can range from a smelly fish to an actual hand cannon. Like weapons, the equipment is quite entertaining. For all of you that like first person shooters, you shouldn't be afraid of this loss in realism. There are still satisfying damage, accuracy, and unlocking systems that are involved. This will keep you coming back to the game for newer and better weapons and/or equipment. In all, combat is fun and takes skill to master the battlefield. I think everyone can agree many games with potential are ruined by a pay-to-win system. This is not true for TF2. Every weapon and piece of equipment can be unlocked randomly throughout the game. You can, however, pay to get something quicker. Also, you are given crates which can be unlocked with a purchased key but again all the stuff can be earned. Some things are harder to get than others so don't expect to get all the great equipment right off the bat. To sum it all up, combat is fair and balanced. As in most games, people create modded servers. These modded servers are, for the most part, fair and do not kill the game. These servers tend to have the most people because they are very enjoyable. While we are on the topic of players, I would like to address the player base. Unfortunately, there are some immature people on the mic. You can avoid this problem by muting them and falling back into the focus of the game play. Other than that, the community is still active and rather fun to play with. All in all, Team Fortress 2 is worth a try. It is a great game you can play with friends and work forever on getting all the achievements. If you are active in the Steam market, items can be traded and sold with ease. I can promise you that you won't regret downloading this game.

game-hours: 382.7
review: This game is amazing. You're seeking for a game that is Free 2 Play and it's a First Person Shooter? You found your gold, buddy. Team Fortress 2 for a game without the need of money has giant content for hours, days, weeks, months, hell even years of fun, doe if you want even more, then you can put some money into it. Maps, hats, shirts, paint cans, keys, spycrabs.... All of it can be bought in Mann Co. Store. You don't need those things to play, but you're gonna gain a lot of respect for owning any of those items. You'll start off with an empty backpack, but soon enough it will be filled with drops. With crafting, you can gain your possition in wealth. Using your weapons you can make scrap metal, and with scrap you'll get reclaimed metal and with that, the glorious refined metal. With enough of these you can start trading, and in no time you'll get the P2P upgrade! With that, you can start making real pile of cash, selling drops, and buying metal, keys and buds, but what to do with those you ask? Well then, you see: In TF2 there is such thing as quality. The stock items are in normal quality items. The next stage is Unique. Those are from drops. Then there's Strange. Now these things are diffrent then regular items in such way that these track for eg.: Kills, Deaths, Assists, etc. After Strange we got Unusual. These things are only for cosmetics and taunts. While in use, there is an effect that apears near the player. Those are quite expesive to be honest. Finally, we have Collector's editions. Those are also very expensive. These are made of tons of the same weapons or cosmetics. The other qualities in the game are: Vintage, Genuine, Haunted(Halloween), Community and Self-Made, but less of that. The gameplay itself isn't as simple as in other FPS games. In here you have 9 classes, all of them with their pros and cons. We got Scout, a fast jerk from Boston with a big mouth. Soldier, an American ready to blow himself up, Pyro the masked mass murderer, Demoman, a Scottish drunken warrior, Heavy, a not so smart Russian with a big gun, Engineer, a cowboy from Texas, ready to sit all day on a chair, Sniper, an Australian head hunter with great aim, Medic, an insane German who created the ber upgrade, and Spy, the French guy who sleept with your mom, and noone ever heard about him. In the end I just want to say that you should deffinetly play this game

game-hours: 578.9
review: The Big Bang Theory is an American sitcom created by Chuck Lorre and Bill Prady, both of whom serve as executive producers on the show along with Steven Molaro. All three also serve as head writers. It premiered on CBS on September 24, 2007. The eighth season premiered on September 22, 2014. The show is primarily centered on five characters living in Pasadena, California: Leonard Hofstadter and Sheldon Cooper, both physicists at Caltech, who share an apartment; Penny, a waitress and aspiring actress who later becomes a pharmaceutical representative, and who lives across the hall; and Leonard and Sheldon's equally geeky and socially awkward friends and co-workers, aerospace engineer Howard Wolowitz and astrophysicist Raj Koothrappali. The geekiness and intellect of the four guys is contrasted for comic effect with Penny's social skills and common sense. Over time, supporting characters have been promoted to starring roles: Bernadette Rostenkowski, Howard's girlfriend (later his wife), a microbiologist and former part-time waitress alongside Penny; neuroscientist Amy Farrah Fowler, who joins the group after being matched to Sheldon on a dating website (and later becomes Sheldon's girlfriend); and Stuart Bloom, the cash-strapped owner of the comic book store the characters often visit, who, in season 8, moves in with Howard's mother.

I liked the concept of the end of the line update, new gamemode. New map, and more. Only problem with that update was it ended up being a load of crap. We got a bunch of awesome stuff from it, but that and. A reskin. Ducks. And miscs. I mean, we could've gotten an awesome new game mode, but apparently a simple game mode is 'too complicated' in Valves eye. Okay Valve, what's your argument for Robot Destruction? I had someone explain it to me and I was still ing confused. Anyway, back on topic. Overall, it's a great game. That Valve sure as hell doesn't give enough love to. But that's on my part. But besides those it's a great game which when I first started, could not get off. My advice if you're starting to get bored of it? review: Casting a hilarious motley of slightly ridiculous characters, Team Fortress 2 sports the best balanced combat in a game I have played, to date. From the (Russian) Heavy's broken english, to the slightly insane (German) Medic shouting insults at his team-mates in his native German, these characters alone have some hilarious voice lines. TF2 has set the benchmark for team based combat, and whilst the teamwork is most prominent in the Payload gamemode (one team pushes a bomb in a minecart along the track, the other team has to stop them), no one class is neccesarily better than any other. Although the Pyro is always checking for spies, the Sniper can drop a Pyro from a well and truly safe distance. A truly brilliant game, and it's free!

game-hours: 269.7
review: Team Fortress 2 is a F2P game now (which honestly, I am a F2P) which means that it is free to play just like I stated earlier. Team Fortress 2 is a online team objective game. The source game that this is running on is Half Life 2, but yet, the art/graphic style of the game, including the sounds and atmosphere, makes it seem like its own game. Trading in this game has been the internets joke about how there is hats in it. Hats/Cosmetic items are equipables you are able to put on your person, just to simply spice him up and look cool. Team Fortress 2 kind of has that atmosphere similar to the "Counter Strike: Global Offensive" being similar with team objectives, & crates. Team Fortress 2 has its very unique 9 different classes, each playing a specific role to the rest of the team. Team Fortress' thrill of playing and finding a random item (doubt it's a strange, EVER) has a bit of a "Oh sweet!" feeling to it. Team Fortress 2 also has custom server game types, such as; The Hidden, Saxton Hale, Dodgeball, Prop Hunt, Wario Ware, etc. To me, this game has it all, it never loses its wow factor and every little thing in the game completely seals the deal for me. So if you're reading this review right now, wondering "Hmm, this guy seems like he knows a bit about it, but he's just one guy.", then just ask one of the 3 to 5 million people playing it today. And I welcome you to the game with open arms. (WARNING: You don't FIND stranges, You either TRADE them, or you UNCRATE them. Which will never happen.) Have a fun time enjoying Team Fortress 2!

game-hours: 151.1
review: The most fun you can have online!
game-hours: 287.3
review: Team Fortress 2 is personally my favorite multiplayer shooter. Ever. Developed by Valve, this game takes elements from classic shooters like Doom, Quake and Unreal and expands upon them, so much so that each of it's 9 classes feel as individual in their playstyles as games like those previously mentioned feel in comparison to the others. When you get into the meat of it, TF2 is the infini-shooter - collecting gamemodes like Capture The Flag and King of The Hill from modern shooters like Call of Duty and Halo while still retaining the arcade-y, fun as hell, gameplay (and adding in some modes of it's own). It has the fantastic sense of humour which Valve are known for, so funny that, to me, shows that more shooters need to be like it and drop the gritty attitude in exchange for a bit of absurd ridiculosity. TF2 also comes with co-op, if you're in the need for some teamwork, in the form of Mann vs Machine, where teams of up to 6 players must defend their base against Gray's evil robot armies, and the fun to be found there is just incredible. TF2 is a game built around teamwork, and it's often worthwhile jumping in on a match just to help you're buddies, the classes are amazingly balanced, the gameplay is amazingly fun and there are hundreds of weapons and accessories to collect, none of which are unbalanced and/or gamebreaking, each of which will alter your looks or your playstyle just enough that it'll keep you coming back, there is also a huge market for trading online with a host of friendly dealers who will inevitably make everyone a lot happier. Did iI mention the game is free. Yes TF2 IS COMPLETELY FREE!

review: Tonight I racked up my 1000th hour in TF2. I started playing this game three years ago as a college freshman, and played off and on until now, my senior year. This game's given me sore wrists, headaches, reduced me to tears of frustration, cost me nearly a hundred dollars worth of cosmetics and most recently broken my laptop's keyboard so I have to type this on a replacement. And I love it. Team Fortress 2 is great. It's got all the stuff you love to see in a game- entertaining characters, fun and varied gameplay between nine brilliantly balanced characters, and a great rotation of cool maps (except Mountain Lab). But what amazes me so much about this game is how many ways there are to play it. I've done tons of regular game types, but that's only part of TF2. You want to listen to fourteen year olds claim they're big wigs on a trade server complain as you stop them from spawncamping? We got that. You want to run around on a Mario Kart map with Gmod screenshots covered in Impact font plastered everywhere? We got that. You want to play a Smash Bros. or zombie mod for stupid gimmick kicks? We got that. And heck yeah you do, those modes are awesome. This game is some of the weirdest and stupidest fun I've ever had with a video game, and I've spent far too much time in it and all the modes above. I've grown a lot as a person with this game (i.e. I don't get so into it I have tantrums anymore, thank Christ), and met a ton of friends I've gotten to play it with too. But come on, dude, the game is free. Tons of people still play it. Download it, jump into a game, and get started! Just don't pick Sniper. So help me God if you play Sniper I will find y

review: Team Fortress 2. How it has improved since its release in 2007! Now it's free to play. Awesome. I must say, I enjoy the gameplay, the graphics, the 9 characters and their different, unique personalities, etc. Many fantastic, 100% explorable maps, for example, Lakeside, 2fort, and Degrootkeep. Among this game's many pros, there's items, like weapons, taunts, and cosmetics (HATS!!). Gamemodes, like Capture the Flag, King of the Hill, Control Points, the fan-made (I think) Vs. Saxton Hale, and my personal favorite, Mann Vs. Machine. This is my favorite Free-to-Play PC game of ALL TIME! I usually put the majority of my free time into playing TF2- that's how much I love playing it! Despite some bad things, like maybe some bugs or glitches, lag, or even players that like to hack the game, I admire this game, everyone involved with it, etc. I would recommend this to everyone in the WORLD if possible! The most fun you can have online is free to play. -PC Gamer
game-hours: 1180.5
review: Absolutely recommended, regardless of whether or not you enjoy FPS games or even games in general. As it is free-to-play, it only costs your time to investigate if this is a game for you. This is the only game that brings a smile to my face and for which I laugh out loud every single time I play it. PROS: -Hilarious team-centered gameplay that can consistently make you laugh out loud even if you're losing a match -Distinct and memorable character classes that suit different play styles -Unique and pleasant graphical fidelity that suits the game's intentions well -Excellent and constantly improving level design -Variety of classic and newer game play modes provide fun for all types of players -Good bots included for offline practice -Wealth of options readily available in-game to ensure the game looks and handles the way you want -Many (emphasis) hats, other cosmetic items, and item modifiers available for customizing your look -Free item drops, with an average 1 random drop per hour -Many free updates that have added weapons, maps, production value, improved performance, story, play modes, and by extension new ways to play the game. All of this has made the game more fun over the years and helped to grow its diverse and largely vibrant community CONS: -The addition of so much content over the years has had some impact on game stability, though this is often fixed eventually via free updates -Some nasty exploits available that can ruin the game for some players, though these are usually eventually fixed via free updates -No obvious classic 'team deathmatch' play mode. The CTF map 2Fort is often used as a team deathmatch map as a result -A lot of the story is explained outside the game via entertaining comics and high quality videos. I am fine with this, though this could frustrate players more interested in storytelling within games -The game is free-to-play, however a minimal monetary investment is required to begin unlocking more than 50 items. There is no pay to win here, however there is definitely more fun to be had when you invest more money in the game to unlock more items. Check this official free-to-play FAQ for more details:

game-hours: 1886.1
review: best free game ever
game-hours: 2450.6
review: While most FPS's strive for realism and grit, TF2 chucks all that out the window in pursuit of a completely outrageous "War-themed hat simulator". The best way to describe TF2 would be to compare it to a Pixar movie like the Incredibles if it was directed by Quentin Tarantino. What sets it apart from other online FPS's is how each class pretty much turns it into a different game and each weapon further alters a class's play style, leading to even further variance. On top of that, the game is so balanced (and no, the spy is not OP, just annoying, get over it) that there is no "class to end all classes", hell it even managed to reclaim the sniper from being a quick-scoping class for people who have no skill to a class that actually requires a bit of skill (I'm talking to you, Call of Duty). Even better than that, the medic class isn't a pathetic idiot with a first aid kit, he is ACTUALLY fun to play, a huge accomplishment. In the case of most FPS's, the developer would simply dump their game on Steam and say "have fun, we'll see you again when the DLC comes out" meaning that it becomes very old very quickly (Call of Duty), TF2 is constantly improving as Valve is keeping it fresh with constant updates, new maps and weapons, meaning that the game gets a make over with every major update. Best of all, you don't have to pay for the new stuff. All this is rounded off by amazing settings that make you imagine yourself as the employee of some super evil organization and with a soundtrack reminiscent of spy thrillers and Saturday morning cartoons as well as a dark sense of humor that keeps you laughing while seeing your recently deceased foe's head sailing past you. An absolutely brilliant FPS for anyone who wants something different in multiplayer games. My only regret is that the like button on this review page can't be mashed repeatedly until it says "I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THIS GAME AND IF THE LAWS OF NATURE WOULD ALLOW IT, I WOULD HAVE ITS CHILDREN!"

game-hours: 1147.3
review: Has this game lost its old charm? Yes. Is it still worth playing? Yes. This game changed a lot over the years, especially because the item economy is now very big and sometimes very annoying when you want/have to deal with it. This didn't hurt the core game, tough. It's still fun, with or without friends, especially because there's a wide variety of maps that will keep you busy for a long time. The nine classes are very unique and offer something for every kind of player, no matter if you prefer direct combat, defensive roles, healing or stealthy assaults. Two things about the game that are quite annoying are for one the fact that it's free to play, which leads to a flood of people who have no idea what they are doing or intentionally are in your way instead of helping you by totally missing the objectives of the game. The other thing is the fact that VALVe recently concentrates on "fixing" things that were either bugs which were loved by the community because they had no negative effect and were just fun to watch or changing basic things that were in the game since the start, like immediately being able to jump after a scoped shot from your sniper rifle. Basically, the game is still fun, but in the old days it was a better experience.

game-hours: 83.6
review: I have dedicated so many hours to this game it is ridiculous. But that is because it is such an addictive game. It's pretty simple run aound and kill people whilst trying to do the objective with other players (basically every other fps out there). But it is unique because of the amount of fun and hours you can throw at it. You can craft, you can trade, you can buy almost every single item in the game. But if you don't fancy doing that you can simply just play the game and you will find items as you play (sometimes). You can dress your character with the latest clothes and hats! And also get special weapons to kit out your person. This game has an incredible humerous, atmosphere to it and it is jam-packed with fun. There are even specials that Valve themselves implement into the game like christmas and halloween items and gamemodes. I can easily say that it is one of the most popular games on the pc as of this day and I can see why. I suggest you get this game as soon as you can (since it's now free!!!) because it will never fail to please you. As of now I haven't found a single glitch or texture problem so the only rating I can give it is: 10/10 Addictive and funny, it is a brilliant game!

review: Team Fortress 2 is a very addictive and interesting free-to-play game. In the game, there are 9 classes you can choose from. Each with their own way of gameplay. Also, there is a lot of negativity saying that you have to "pay to win" going towards the "MannCo. Store" (A store that allows you to pay real money for weapons, hats, miscs, and overall just in-game items). This is false since in Team Fortress 2 there are "random drops" where the player could get lucky and find a weapon for free in the game. Basically, just download the game and play it. review: There's a point where I can write a review that can be both amazing yet bias at the same time; I hope I don't try to influence anyone by this review alone. When I first got Team Fortress 2, it was an experience that can't be beat. This first-person shooter can't go to say that this is probably the greatest in gaming history. From trading to crafting, this game will keep you on th edge of your seat until you know it's ready to stop playing. There are 9 classes, each that is unique and makes the game fairly balanced, making th game experience even more fun. With all the updates, there are some positive and negative effects than can affect the Team Fortress 2 trading community as a whole, but the whole aspect is to game, have fun, and enjoy your time on this game. It's your decision to buy from the store. It's your decision to craft metal and hats. It's your decision to play, idle, or even be a teammate and balance the rosters. The community is just like this game: random. So if you wish to stop playing other FPS titles and take a break from imbalanced games, then your choice is this: you won't be dissapointed.

review: This game has no redeeming quality anywhere within, it has absolutley no engaging gameplay aspects whatsoever, the gameplay is just too straightforward, and overall it feels like I'm playing some 12-year-olds school project. That's what some people would say, and yes I do agree with them, but this game is just so strangely addicting, I can't seem to get off. The game combines elements from most First-Person-Shooters, but it also throws in some RPG elements like Random Critical Hits, and different weapons with different stats. I have no idea why this game is so strangely addicting, but it just is. Oh, and it's free-to-play, that's a nice touch.

review: its better then what it was
game-hours: 465.7
review: This game is a diffrent type of first person shooter. You have nine diffrent classes that you can freely choose from and play. All classes have their pros and cons, so no class is overpowered. The graphics is cartoonish. The goal with the game is to finish the map objective before the time runs out. It can be anything from pushing a cart to eliminating the other team. It even exsists custom game modes out there. This game is all about the objective. You start out with stock weapons (and hats) on all classes. You get new weapons and hats by playing the game or purchasing it from the store. Purchasing items from the store will upgrade your game to premium. Premium members get more inventory space, abillity to trade and higher chance to get rare items. All items have a diffrent playstyle. Most official servers and all community servers can be played on for free(some community servers have additional premium features). All official servers that host "man vs machine" in "man-up" mode requires a ticket to play. This game mode grants you a chance to get rare loot if you make it to the end. Pros: - Play and have fun for free. - Diffrent weapons have diffrent play styles. - Crafting system. - More focus on points rather than kill-death ratio. - Most type of weapons can be obtained without a premium membership. - Very cheap premium. - Not pay to win. - Nice and fair maps. - Works on Windows, Mac and Linux. Cons: - Some class weapons can be overpowered. - You might be called a noob if you don't have cool hats. - Few new updates. - Some menus are a little bit too complicated. - You will in certain cases meet players that doesn't care about the objective!

game-hours: 999.2
review: If you ignore some part of the toxic community including tryhards, crazy people who yell at your team for not doing a simple thing, and the occasional pro that kicks your ? This game scores high on the field. The many things of this game is relatively likeable, you're given new weapons to toy with from the drop system that changes how the game is played little by little, each and every weapon can alter the style of how you play, and as a result, makes you feel like you're kinda creating your own build. There are loads of cosmetic items and hats to customize with that when people get to that stage of getting those cosmetic items and paints, people can make an appearance of themselves in the game that distinguishes them. Even Free to Players can get a variety of hats for free and use them, but most of all, the majority of the game's community. But it's not the hats that make the player, it's the dedication and how the game works. Every now and then, sure, you'll come across a squeaker or even an arrogant fool that brags about killing you every time, but most of all? What makes games fun is when the teams are both on balance beams, but you're capable of playing against up to thirty-two people on a server, usually, or, by Valve standard's, twenty-four. The characters, being suited for different roles in the game are comical, colorful, and fleshed out, given their own personality and having their own unique, lovable shine to them, where unlike other games with most classes, people sound like they have the same voice actor, or even the same two or three voice actors, where it this game, the voices for the characters are quite indistinguishable and marvelously done by the team in that sector, despite some classes sharing the same voice actor. The game is portrayed in a cartoonish art style in which the characters are represented well for it. The game allows you to have Offline practice which even then can challenge you with what you're doing, Normal mode alone pits you up against multiple engineers, and occasionally a Sniper and Spy, and a normal team functions identically to that as an average team of people on Team Fortress 2 (Safe for the Medic, occasionally, where I died right in front of the AI when lit afire and calling for him with no medpack in sight.). Which Normal is the best difficulty to hone your skills, though Easy too, can be occasionally challenging. Every online game is not relatively geared to be the same, too. You're pit up with likely people you've never even met. And what these people do is what makes that game feel different, you might make friends, you might make rivals, you might see new techniques, you might see something silly. Not every game in TF2 is the same compared to most team-based shooters, which is absolute rush down or too much centered upon simple quickscoping, and shooting. In order to get better at the game, you need to be more aware of your surroundings, what is happening, and not only this, but to counter the playstyle of players in the game, which you may or may not do. The only bad points this game has had is some bugs, exploits, and occasionally, you may find a hacker if you're unlucky enough. But this game originally started as a Quake Mod, and then has went through nine years of development, and now, up to this point, we've got a masterpiece which all of it's years had paid off it's potential. 95%

No game is perfect, but Team Fortress 2 isn't far from it. I wholeheartedly recommend this masterpiece to any gamer worth his/her salt.

game-hours: 256.8
review: If you like First person shooters with some class, this is the game for you.
game-hours: 304.1
review: Let's talk about one of my favorite games on Steam, TF2. I know it's kinda strange to review a game that is free, since pretty much anybody can play it, but I really want to share my thoughts on it, since I think it's awesome. Also, this is my first review on Steam, so please let me know what you think. Let's talk about the graphics first. Usually, First Person Shooter games consist of realistic graphics with a military theme. All of these games look almost the same, with very minor differences, that you can barely tell them apart from each other. TF2 however, went for a very cartoonish artsytle, making it stand out from the crowd. The graphics are also over the top, with tons of explosions, blood and body parts flying all over the area, but at the same time it feels lighthearted because of the artsyle, adding to the humor of the game. To sum it up, the graphics are very unique and add to the charm of the game. Next let's talk about the most important part of the game, the gameplay. For anyone who is a fan of singleplayer only games, you might be disappointed, since the game is online only (there is a practice mode where you can battle against bots, but they obviously feel very artificial). There's also no story, well sort of. All of the story of the game is told through comics that you can read on the TF2 website, but are not available in game. So yeah, this game is pure multiplayer, but that's not a bad thing at all. I am a person that usually tends to dislike FPS games where the focus of the game is multiplayer like Call of Duty, since it doesn't require too much skill in my opinion, only fast reactions which causes tons of rage. TF2 however , is different in that regard too. This game requires a TON of skill, and because of that it might be offputting for new players, but if you stick for a while, you will see how satisfying pulling off an awesome trick is. Also, unlike many FPS games where you can pretty much do everything on your own , in TF2 you HAVE to work as a team, after all, It's called Team Fortress, not Me Fortress. Trying to fight three enemies, or more at a time WILL NOT work for you AT ALL. Instead, you have to rely on your team, which also adds to the strategy of the game. Believe me, there's a lot of strategy in this game, a lot more than you might think, one of those being the classes which I will talk about right now. The classes are one of the things that really make this game unique. There are nine classes, each having their own stats and playstyle. The thing is, they are very well balanced. Each of the classes completely change the way that you play the game, so if you get bored of playing a certain class, no problem, because you can change into another class at any given time. I'm not going to talk about each one, but believe me, the things that each of the classes does well, they do the best, but each also has their lowpoints, which is why the classes are very well balanced. There are also many game modes, adding even more to the variety of the game. All of that was before the game became Free to Play, so what was added since then, and is it a Pay to Win kind of game? The answer: alot, and not at all, In fact, TF2 is one of the most complete F2P games I have ever played. So what do you get in advantage of being a paid player? Hats. Seriously, hats. Do they add you some sort of an extraordinary power that makes you completly overpowered, making it that nobody can beat you? No, just hats and other cosmetics that don't change a darn thing, other than making you look fancy. For most of the community, hats are some the most important things in TF2, leading to tons of trades and paying actual money in order to become the fanciest of them all. I personally don't really care for the hats, only about the gameplay, but many players enjoy that, so if trading's your thing, go ahead. Other than what I've said, what else you can buy with actual money? Weapons. The weapons however, can be found randomly by each player and a lot of these completely change your playstyle, adding even more to the variety. I really like the weapons system in the game, mostly because a lot of the times, you don't put yourself in an advantage for using them, heck, sometimes it's even better to use your stock weapons that each class starts with. So why use them? Simply because they are fun. They are also very well balanced (well, most of them...), so again, you don't put yourself too much in an advantage for using them. So, basically you really don't need to become a paid player in order to enjoy the game. The thing is, becoming a paid player is as cheap as you want it to be. You decide how much you want to pay in order to become a paid player, and that's pretty cool. Another thing, the game keeps being updated, despite being 7 years old, making it feel fresh. Next, I'll talk in a brief about the game's charm. I've already talked about the graphics, but what other things make the game charming? Well, the characters. Besides playing differently, they all have their own personality and in game quotes. Some of the quotes are really funny, and the characters' personalities really shine in that regard. Also, TF2 has some of the most clever advertising I have ever seen:the "Meet the..." videos, where the characters' personalities shine even more. I really recommend you watching them since they are awesome. So these are all the positives, are there any negatives? Yes there are. First, the auto balancing in this game can become EXTREMLY annoying. At some points you will score many points for the team, almost close to a victory, to then be moved to the other team, resulting in a loss, which is obviously very frustrating. Next, there are many bugs and glitches, but that to be expected from a big game as this. And third... THE RANDOM CRITICAL HITS!!! I HATE THEM!!! Two other negatives that I have aren't really Valve's fault but I will say them anyways. First, the community can be extremly annoying at times. How? By making fun of Free to Play players. They think that just because they don't pay, it makes them bad at the game. That logic annoys me, since I've seen F2P players that are better than some that just like to brag about their hats, but if that does happen to you, just ignore them and enjoy the game. Second, is that because the game has been out for quite a while, there are many skilled players here, which can really frustrate newcomers, but as I've said before, stick for a while, and it will get much better. In conclusion, I think TF2 is a fantastic game, possibly the best free game I've ever played. If you haven't already, please play it, it's free, so you have nothing to lose. For those asking for a score, I'll give it somewhere between 9 and 9.5 out of ten. The reason for that score is that I think no game is perfect, but there many great games out there and this is one of them. Highly recommended for everyone, even for those who dislike the genre, like me.

game-hours: 135.3
review: Team Fortress 2 is the sequel to Valve's Team Fortress Classic. It is a class based, action packed, and highly addictive first person shooter. If your tired of generic first person games that take little to no skill, than this is the game for you. It is a simple game in concept, but is made more strategic when you consider the different classes this game has to offer. So it will keep you busy for a long time. Now in terms of the presentation, it's nice. The interface is clean and compliments the gameplay very well. Every gun has a really good sound effect to it. Last but not least, the price. There is none. Well, if you want you can buy cosmetic items and different weapons. The different weapons are very well balanced though. So you can't buy your way to the top. Overall, get this game. It's free and fun.

game-hours: 2759.3
review: It started when I heard about a Burning Team Captain that sold for thousands. So in a spark mad of genius I doused an old police hat in gasoline, and placed it proudly on my RL hat slot as I gaily ran off to find a source of ignition not only to set my custodian aflame, but my very heart. The flame greedily consumed it's liquid offering as ravenously as OP would devour a bag of di -cks. The now burning fuel from the hat had dribbled down onto my once very non-nauseating face. I quickly shielded my eyes exclaiming, "NO I NEED THOSE FOR GAMING!". I was able to protect my boob ooglers from the intense heat which blazed like the fury of a thousand suns (and a cup of lukewarm chamomile tea) , but I was not able to spare much else from the ensuing facepocalypse. The still agonizing third degree burns had transformed me into a smoldering monster. The flesh once pink, and rosey now charred black with specks of red where blood threatened to ooze amidst the aftermath I once called my mask slot (I also like Payday 2). More scab than man. Upon hobbling over to the nearest mirror to inspect the damage I was at first in shocked disbelief unable to comprehend the horror of the image that stood before me, but the very moment I saw that hideous creature stare back into my soul I knew that very instant I would never again know the warmth of a woman. Fortunately dating is expensive, and I can spend that money on keys. All in all a win win.

game-hours: 659.8
review: Dear reader, have you ever played DayZ, spawned and was killed by some man (or woman, i dont discriminate) with an ungodly amount of weapons? Perhaps you played Call of Duty, and helplessly watched as your entire team was killed by someone throwin a grenade. Shenanigans are fun when you have the say in who it goes to, but what if you wanted a game that actually requires skill? Look no further than TF2! this is a game that is serious, but doesnt take itself too seriously. With Valve servers you can duke it out with other players in a fair match, or play in a community made server and bend the rules till your hearts content! The game lacks the weapons that most FPSs base themselves on. To do the most damage you need to get up close and personal with your scatter gun, and dash away before you get yourself killed. This game bases itself and its game play on nine classes, with their own individuel story, perks, stats, and weapon setups. Each class requires different skills to play. Example to effectivly play a good soldier, one would need to understand the speed of the rocket, and the direction the enemy is going. Using this infromation, plus a couple others, you can dispatch this enemy and move onto the next. Not into the whole thinking before doing thing? TF2 has a class for that! Play as the pyro or medic. Either way this game has something for everyone. Those who want a serious game play experiance can use the Highlander servers. Those who want to look fly and nifty can go on trade servers. Why are you not downloading this game? Do you not like fun? I promise you there is a server for you, there is a fandom for you, and there is a faction for you! ThatBronyGuy thinks this game is swell.

Also the hats, miscs and weapons are all great from your starting weapons, to strange weapons with thousands of kills after a while. Alltogether, I think TF2 is a game worth playing no matter where your from.

review: It has been #1018 days since I first played Team Fortress 2. This game changed my life forever. It taught me how the world economy works and how virtual hats are consider ten times better than actual real life hats. I'm wasting my life savings on purchasing virtual keys to open virtual crates in hopes of receiving a nice hat with some special particle effect called an unusual. I wasted over $200 dollars on the Mann Co. store and I don't regret it because all of my money goes to Lord Gaben as he swims in his pile of cash. Ever since I got this game, I've been failing school, my family disowned me, my girlfriend left me, and my friends refuse to talk to me. However, Tf2 has always sticked around for me till the end so I'll continue to play this game. I wake up every morning leaving Tf2 on my computer and being ready for a game. I go to the local store to buy poptarts, Mountain Dew, and Ramen for fuel to play tf2. I sometimes make a sandvich if I feel like I want to eat something healthy. Tf2 is my life and I can't live without it. Without tf2, my life has no meaning. 10/10, Tf2 overall is one of the best games ever made. It's not just a game, but a lifestyle I taken. game-hours: 1588.7
review: Team Fortress 2. What is it there to say that hasn't already been said? It's a fast paced FPS with a cartoony art style with funny characters and decent story (atleast from comics cause the games have like no story). Since this is an online game you are gonna play with other people. Choose 1 of the 9 classes. The classes are: Scout: the fast cocaine expert. Soldier: the kitten savior. Pyro: the hated. Demoman: the guy who can't make up his mind on what he wants to be played as. Heavy: the goofy character that is pretty much everywhere on TF2 things except update love. Engineer: the character where you litteraly sit down and watch your guns do the talking. Medic: the character with a great personality but no one wants to play. Sniper: no chest hair. Spy: the character everyone wants to play. As you can tell the classes are different from each other and playing each class feels like a different game,and each charcater has their own charm to keep them interesting and unique. The Community: The community in TF2 can be good or bad,depending on your view. On one side you'll have some very nice and friendly people being cute little butterflies while others are about as nice as Mike Tyson biting your ear off. Here's the list of some people you'll meet. The class balancer: this guy usualy wants a really balanced team even in pubs. Side effects may include rage from the player complaining about 5 snipers on his team. The Pubstomper: this guy goes on pubs stomping every last person showing off his skills. Side effects may include server population ending up low,rage from new players and rage from the pubstomper when he gets killed. The Competetive player: this guy is usualy on competetive servers being a professional and telling people he's 1337 on TF2. Side effects may include a lot of "I don't care" from most people. The Trader: this creature's place is usualy on trade servers but sometimes somehow the creature finds himself in a pub and then binds his or her, or its key to "Selling BlazboBibbin's beard for 35 ref". Side effects may include a team member who only knows trading and not much fighting like a fruit vendor. The idler: This guy is a worser version of the trader because the idler just sits in spawn doing nothing not knowing there's a idle server or not knowing valve took away idling in a update. They are also probably watching pornography until they notice they got kicked out of the server. Side effects may include a useless teammate making it a little easier for the enemy team to win. The micspammer: Ever had those times when you are hearing random music in a server for no reason? Congratulations you've met the micspammer who thinks his music is so great he would play it over his mic so that everyone can listen to it. Side effects may include a lot of kicking and muting (sadly people seem to forget there's muting). The whiner: This person always whines and says very nice things to people that kill him. "OH MY FRAKIN GOD U IN HAKKER I KNOW UR HAKKIN' OH OH I WILL FRAKIN GET DA ADMIN TO BAN YOU YOU FA-G-G-OT". His nice things can also usualy be heard in the mic. Side effects may include broken ears and a need to kick the whiner's face on his birthday. Maps: TF2 has many maps and they're about as original as they can get. You got your egyptian,forest,building,desert themes. Knowing the classes in this game,Valve thought it would be a good idea to have almost every map a giant corridor. There are some exceptions like Egypt for example but most maps are so narrow that the areas are usualy spammed to death by pipebombs and rockets it almost feels like you need a giant brick wall with you. There are also community maps that use the same themes as the developer maps and there are some maps that are unique A.K.A use themes from other games or movies. Gamemodes: Gamemodes are just multiple versions of one gamemode which is CP. There's attack/defend where one team defends while the other attacks. There's regular CP which both teams capture points like a weird version of connect the dots. There's KOTH which is 1 point and hold it for 3 minutes because that means things. There's Payload a unique version of CP in the fact that you can only capture the points with a bomb cart which does has its charm. CTF which has the worst maps in the entire game. SD only has one map, not counting the halloween map, where it's a combination of CTF and king of the hill. There are also custom gamemodes from the community. Some are things like Super Smash bros. which is basicaly Smash Bros. but with TF2 physics,Slender which is well Slender except with more things than just Slenderman,Dodgeball which more feels like homing rocket tennis than dodgeball and much,much more. Overall TF2 is a game where it's free but you still end up paying money hoping you get an unusual hat and show it off to people so that they can see you're the god of all things and then all of them,including you, realize that you still get your butt kicked by a regular person. Also a game filled with bugs that are questionably not fixed like Heavy not having hands or random cosmetics flying in the air and other stuff. This game is very successful even for a 7 year old game and many other people will play it forever and ever and ever and ever and ever and ever and ever and *10000 years later* and ever and ever. Honestly I did get bored of the game that I don't really wanna play it that much anymore so yeah uh... Bye

review: This game is easy to pick up and play, but there is also a lot of meta-game to learn and improve on. You can play casually with frlends or foes, or take the competition to lobbies and pick-up games. If you really love the idea of the game, but public games and/or lobbies are too casual for you, you can join or form a team to participate in tournaments with, such as UGC, ETF2L, ESEA and even top level LANs if you become good enoough. There is something for everybody in this game, and I thoroughly recommend it to anyone interested.

review: FPS Shooter games have been spread out around the world becoming popular, but when it comes to TF2 it's like no other. It's simply made and easy to play just like the way it's made, it's different every day with new thing's to do with new updates, including taunts, cosmetics, and loads more, building up the game. What makes TF2 a unique game apart from COD and BF is that it's not as big as those games, well ofcourse it has loads of stuff, but not as sophisticated as the other FPS shooters. It does not have singleplayer, not that (extreme) graphics and including other more features that other games have and not TF2. But not having features like COD or BF makes it better and unique not worse and more repetitive, therefore when COD or BF players try TF2 for the first time they don't really understand the concept of the game, which explains the game is unique. Overall TF2 is an addictive and unique Game with lots to discover, hoping the game get's better. 10/10

game-hours: 736.7
review: Team fortress 2 is cool
game-hours: 1971.5
review: Team Fortress 2 is a class-based shooter filled with personality and fun that can keep you entertained for ages. There are nine classes to choose from that fit any play style or situation that may be throw at you. These class are the: Scout, Soldier, Pyro, Demoman, Heavy, Engineer, Medic, Sniper and Spy. The Scout is a fast paced, double jumping class featuring a Scatter Gun that is deadly up-close. The Soldier (my favourite) is given a rocket launcher and, to compensate for his slow movement, has the ability to rocket jump which can propel him faster and further than any class could dream of going. The Pyro is a mysterious being that has a deep love for fire and burning things and is given a flame thrower to do just that. The Demoman is a 'black, Scottish cyclops' who specialises in explosives wielding a stickybomb launcher that can be fired at any surface to attach remotely detonated explosives to surprise enemies. He also has the ability to turn into a 'demoknight', sporting a sword and shield that lets him charge at his enemies and take their heads. Next is the Heavy. This slow talking Russian is armed with 'Sasha', a incredibly large minigun capable of destroying anything that comes near it. Because of this, the Heavy moves very slowly and, because of his... stature, is an big target for anyone. The Heavy is also the tank of the classes featuring the largest health pool in the game. The Engineer is the brains of the group. He has the ability to build buildings such as sentries, dispensers and teleporters which helps out his team in defending (or attacking) areas. The Medic is the healer of the group, wielding a medigun instead of actual medical knowledge. He is able to heal his targeted team mate and give them overheal so they may sustain more damage. His role is to keep everyone alive and, if he's been healing for long enough, give them an Ubercharge which grants him and his heal target 8 seconds of invulnerability. The Sniper is fairly standard class in most shooters but TF2 has thrown a twist on the class. His sniper rifle features a modification which allows for higher damage the longer the user is scoped in. Aim for the head when sniping, otherwise the sniper rifle will do a third of the damage. The Spy is the stealth class, favouring invisibility and disguises to avoid confrontation and then to kill targets instantly with his knife's backstab. He is also able to sap enemy Engineer's buildings which disables and eventually destroys them. Constantly updating, TF2 has a growing community which means you will always find a match or someone to trade with. Whether it be in game or on one of the community made trade websites, someone out their wants your hats. It's free and fun, why wouldn't you try it?

game-hours: 1119.8
review: Now before I begin, Team Fortress 2 is an epic first person shooter game from the start. A summary of the story would be how two companies (teams) are fighting to claim land. 9 mercenaries have been hired to fight for the land. Each mercenary is quite different from each other, and have their own specific role. The game is quite fun and is mostly focuses on team work, and communicating. You also find and trade tons of weapons, gear and, hats throughout the game. The game is not pay to win as you can find every weapon in the game :P, and if you find the same weapon you can craft them into different weapons or hats!!! Another alternative is to trade with your friends online, or to buy them in the shop. Unlike most other games, team fortress 2 has many game modes, a few of them are: CTF, KOTH (King of the Hill), Payload( Move a bomb into the enemies base, and watch as it explodes :D), Capture control points, and boss fights! There are tons of maps you can play some made by the creators of tf2, Valve, and custom maps made by awesome people like yourself. There are many cool updates, in which new equipment and maps are added to the game. Want to see what people have created, and hope in adding? Then, visit the steam workshop for tf2 and explore! Hey, did I mention that even you, yes YOU can create an item in hope of it getting added to the game :D And on top of that people create thousands of funny, amazing animations using SFM(Source film maker) using TF2 :D. O and if you want to be different from the rest, well not to worry as you can customize how your mercenaries look like with hats, cosmetics and even more hats :D! Would rate it a 100/10

game-hours: 217.7
review: The tomato is the edible, often red fruit/berry of the nightshade Solanum lycopersicum,[1][2] commonly known as a tomato plant. The species originated in the South American Andes[2] and its use as a food originated in Mexico, and spread throughout the world following the Spanish colonization of the Americas. Its many varieties are now widely grown, sometimes in greenhouses in cooler climates. The tomato is consumed in diverse ways, including raw, as an ingredient in many dishes, sauces, salads, and drinks. While it is botanically a fruit, it is considered a vegetable for culinary purposes (as well as under U.S. customs regulations, see Nix v. Hedden), which has caused some confusion. The fruit is rich in lycopene, which may have beneficial health effects. The tomato belongs to the nightshade family, Solanaceae.[1][3] The plants typically grow to 13 meters (310 ft) in height and have a weak stem that often sprawls over the ground and vines over other plants. It is a perennial in its native habitat, although often grown outdoors in temperate climates as an annual. An average common tomato weighs approximately 100 grams (4 oz).[4][5]Etymology The word "tomato" comes from the Spanish tomate, which in turn comes from the Nahuatl word tomatotl /atomatl/.[6] It first appeared in print in 1595. A member of the deadly nightshade family, tomatoes were erroneously thought to be poisonous (although the leaves are) by Europeans who were suspicious of their bright, shiny fruit. Native versions were small, like cherry tomatoes, and most likely yellow rather than red. The tomato is native to western South America and Central America.[6] Mesoamerica Aztecs and other peoples in Mesoamerica used the fruit in their cooking. The exact date of domestication is unknown: by 500 BC, it was already being cultivated in southern Mexico and probably other areas.[7]:13 The Pueblo people are thought to have believed that those who witnessed the ingestion of tomato seeds were blessed with powers of divination.[8] The large, lumpy variety of tomato, a mutation from a smoother, smaller fruit, originated in Mesoamerica, and may be the direct ancestor of some modern cultivated tomatoes.[7] Spanish distribution Spanish conquistador Hernn Corts may have been the first to transfer the small yellow tomato to Europe after he captured the Aztec city of Tenochtitlan, now Mexico City, in 1521, although Christopher Columbus, a Genoese working for the Spanish monarchy, may have taken them back as early as 1493. The earliest discussion of the tomato in European literature appeared in an herbal written in 1544 by Pietro Andrea Mattioli, an Italian physician and botanist, who suggested that a new type of eggplant had been brought to Italy that was blood red or golden color when mature and could be divided into segments and eaten like an eggplantthat is, cooked and seasoned with salt, black pepper, and oil. However it wasn't until ten years later that tomatoes were named in print by Mattioli as pomi doro, or "golden apple".[7]:13 After the Spanish colonization of the Americas, the Spanish distributed the tomato throughout their colonies in the Caribbean. They also took it to the Philippines, from where it spread to southeast Asia and then the entire Asian continent. The Spanish also brought the tomato to Europe. It grew easily in Mediterranean climates, and cultivation began in the 1540s. It was probably eaten shortly after it was introduced, and was certainly being used as food by the early 17th century in Spain. The earliest discovered cookbook with tomato recipes was published in Naples in 1692, though the author had apparently obtained these recipes from Spanish sources.[7]:17 In certain areas of Italy, such as Florence, however, the fruit was used solely as a tabletop decoration before it was incorporated into the local cuisine in the late 17th or early 18th century. Italy

game-hours: 93.9
review: Well what can I say, THE epitome of free games is this one, there really isn't a pay-to-win scenario, as you can randomly get items you normally have to pay for by just playing the game, and who can forget idling back in the day? You can run this game on nearly any computer due to its low SysReqs. I remember having my first Steam account 5 years ago, which is long gone due to forgetting my password. And having only one game, it was this one. I had never played anything like this at the time, as I was mainly a console game at that point. Another positive of this game is the community is great, there isn't really any modders on it, unlike the Xbox version which is nearly unplayable right now. Also, beware of the Spies, probably a majority of my deaths on this game are from Pyros and Spies, those little s. There is also a myriad of maps out there made by community members, some of them like Harvest, are one of the maps you'll probably play the most. Also if you own Garry's mod, you get TF2 maps, character models, and assets from the game to use in Garry's mod. The classes are well balanced and it has a lot of replay value, as illustrated by some other reviewers with 700+ hours on the game. And now onto the cons Some people mic spam, it is rare but it happens and sometimes you get into competitive games and you get cursed out by some 36 year old man who is taking everything way too seriously. Or you get some one with a horrible connection who makes the game nearly unplayable. That is about it for cons, and for the review also. 9.5/10 is my final verdict What are you waiting for?! Download this game NOW!

review: Team Fortress 2 a fun based animated shooting game that includes and 9 class character selection divided into 3 groupes attack,support and defend the 2 teams are BLU BuildersLeagueUnited and RED ReliableExcavationDemolition. The 9 classes consits of Scout who can run fast and double jump , Soilder can rocket jump and is a damage dealer , Pyro who can air blast projectiles with the alt click button the mouse and ambush others , Demo who can do traps with sticks and suprise enimes with rolling grenaids ,Heavy who can deal damge and is known as the bullet sponge, Engineer who can builde teleporters, sentrys and dispensers which provide ammo, health and metal for engie to build, Medic can heal with hismedi gun and ubercharge making the healer and the healie invunrable for a short amount of time the medic also has a regenaration of his health when he walks, Sniper who can deal damage with head shots or crit body shots and Spy who can do 1 hit kill backstabs and discise kit which can turn you into all 9 classes and can sap all engie buildings and cloak in and out i for one think its a great game and i think you all shal enjoy this game my rating ***** 5 stars outta five stars good job Valve :)

review: Team Fortress 2 neither focuses on your kill/death ratio nor how many matches you won or lost. It's all about having fun. And unlike most first-person shooters, this game requires teamwork more a person's individual skills. This game even has the most unique economy. Most items you buy or find still retain some value you can use to trade with other players around the world. Heck, even the people who play this game could make the next great weapon or item and earn a piece of the profits. Best of all, this game is free to play. You have nothing to lose for trying this!

review: I believe one of the main reasons this game is so popular is because of the fact you know you'll be rewarded will random items. Now keep in mind this raindom reward system only lasts so long before you say to yourself "I have pretty much everything I want." But in that time you learn more about what you can do to those weapons you love oh so much. Oh you're pretty good with the Black Box? Lets make it strange and killstreak for a dollar and keep playing to show how great you are with it. Another charming thing about this game is you can get almost every weapon by chance. So if you don't have money to burn, all you have to do is play the game and soon you'll have your own stockpile of weapons or you can just trade other players or even craft the weapon yourself! Another thing about this game is the characters. Although we don't know too much about the characters other than their respective 'Meet the ___" videos and other animations, I like what we know them as now. But my favorite has to be the Pyro. I love Pyro because they didn't make him out to be the '2edgy4 mysterious badass cool guy who is the living form of hatred', like most games who have a fire based masked man who uses fire. Pyro is just your casual insane arsonist who lives in a world of sunshine and gumdrops. He behaves like your average TF2 character, badass in their own respect and derpy.

review: Well, for the few people left who don't play TF2, this game is AWESOME. The best part is: 100% absolutely FREE. No hoops to jump through, no fees to pay, money saved. Money is spent optionally. Who knows if you want to, but TF2 is fun without it.

review: The core game is fine, it's not P2W, the most important items are dropped via achievements, and the stock items are in many cases the best anyways. What for me destroys the game is the focus on hats or general cosmetic items. For the most part of the community and Valve now, it's no longer about the gameplay. It really is for many players just the Hat Simulator #1, and that's just not my thing. I recommend the game regardless, because although the game can be better if they would focus more on the gameplay, it's a solid shooter with a good class system and a nice art style.

review: An interesting concept in a game. The first I've heard of to be an FPS game meant to be funny, in which it is highly successful. The taunt system adds infuriating humour to the defeated and the comical lines voiced by the 9 classes are hysterical. I rate TF2 with a 9/10 for humour thanks to that system. The game has very little lag problems, being able to easily run on even poor computers. I rate TF2 with a 10/10 for lag. The game is fun and original, with dozens of ways to play. I rate TF2 an 8/10 for gameplay. The game has great graphics for a game that came from 2007, and still has good graphics to this day. I rate TF2 7/10 on graphics. review: Amazing game! I don't play as much anymore but I have tons of experience. The economy is amazing, like CS:GO but with more stuff. Item qualities, hats & miscs metal & keys. It's awesome. The trading just makes you want to keep playing. The economy is just so in depth, and it takes experience to really take advantage of the things provided to you to play. The game is very fun. Not that tactical and strategic like CS:GO, and doesn't take as much skill, but still. The classes have their own approach and way of play, and so does the weapons. MvM is very fun to play with friends, and Mann Up Mode is fun, and owrth it once you get that amazing Bot Killer. Friendly players, (Sometimes) and fun game-modes like Saxton Hale. Different modifications like 100% crits, and Randomizer or filled with laughter and fun. My only critisism is Achievement servers, most servers are those these days, and how un-user friendly the game is at first. Good game all the least, just saying. The concept is very simple, and the different gamemodes are very fun. The sniping is very easy, it's a dead on shot, regardless if you're scoped in or not, which is kind of boring. Rocket jumping is very fun. Surfing/pogo-ing might take practice, but it's very worth it once you can get to one end of the map to the other in in matters of seconds! I give this this game a Ghostly Gibus out of 10!

game-hours: 510.0
review: This game... This game... I have dedicated over 200 hours of playing time to this game, leaving every other game in my library collect dust (with the exception of fallout new vegas), however; I feel like I could easily put in another 1000 hours without getting bored. This game is, by no means, a free to play, play to win, but it is very tempting to spend hundreds of dollars on cosmetics, stranges, killstreaks, and (of course) hats. most of the things that truly make the game more exciting, such as new strategic weapons, are obtained through time and determinations, not money. There is a very strong continuum of skill throughout the game, making some servers too difficult or too easy, depending on chance. The latest update, while rebuked by some, is actually quite interesting. The new weapons aren't too underwhelming and the gifts are pretty excitng, like a raffle of sorts. Overall, it is one of my favorite games and one I hope will stay around for another six years. Update: 9.5/10 still no Star Wars hats.

game-hours: 100.6

game-hours: 1380.1
review: This comes from the perspective of someone who is relatively new-ish, having only played the game for not even half a year. I also do not play on sponsored or competitive servers, which would probably be more ideal for me. Quite a bit of my playtime has been in pub servers; think of it as being thrown into a cesspool (like your average high school). Overall, considering how much time I have sunk into this game (not to mention the money) I feel it is time to say a word or two about it, good and bad. Team Fortress 2, as indicated by the first word in its name, is built on the concept of teamwork. The second word indicates the difficult obstacle of surpassing an enemy team and whatever "fortress" contains the objective. And the number "2", because there was a game before this one. Unlike any other multiplayer game I have ever played, teamwork is embodied by the numerous strategies and accomplishments of its various and unique classes working together. Skill plays a part, as always, but a great team will overcome any obstacle and utterly wall an incompetent one. You will then be disappointed to learn that most players will learn of this concept, think briefly for a moment, then toss the book in the river. Never is this game more frustrating when witnessing "team"-mates make many, many, MANY uninformed or questionable decisions that literally toss the enemy team a cookie every five seconds or exuberates the small, but notable, technical issues of the game that can work against you. I could fill a novel with examples, such as pyros never extinguishing their allies or medics withholding ubers while under heavy enemy fire or, indeed, players who spam engineer and sniper class and spend most of the game sitting on their  doing nothing, but that would be redundant. I will also spare you the rant of "easy button" weapons or technical issues because I am sure people have made entire documentaries on great topics such as "Sticky Spam" or "Baby Face Speed Demon" or, without a doubt, the famous "Hit Detection, Myth or Reality?" that has the praise and contempt of many scholars on the subject. What, just barely, makes all the nonsense that would make any sane person french kiss Sasha (with the trigger pulled, of course) worth it are the moments when teammates abide by the concept. When that sniper headshots a heavy about to bear down upon you, or the pyro airblasts an ubered heavy-medic combo from a sentry nest, or the scout protects the medic from another hounding scout, or a group works in concert to protect their heavy-medic combo with covering fire while pushing forward, and so on and so forth. Those moments are amazing and make any game, even one that is utlimately lost, a joy to play through. When people work together and are willing to make sacrifices for their allies, even at the cost of their precious killstreak, and in turn those allies are thankful and return the favor somehow, is that not what this game is about? Is this not TEAM Fortress 2? This is a game that contains some of the greatest multiplayer experiences you will ever come to know and remember, but only when you and others understand and abide by the name of the game. Otherwise, you will tred many boring stalemates or be on the wrong end of a one-sided conflict or simply run into the wrong crowd of people before you ever happen upon the right game. But, again, I suppose it is worth it for the moments where you meet amazing people and taste sweet victory achieved by all of your sweat, blood, and rage-inducing spasms.

game-hours: 260.9
review: Uh Not too sure what to write here so heres a recipe for Pancakes instead Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups all-purpose flour 3 tablespoons sugar 1 tablespoon baking powder 1/4 teaspoon salt 1/8 teaspoon freshly ground nutmeg 2 large eggs, at room temperature 1 1/4 cups milk, at room temperature 1/2 teaspoon pure vanilla extract 3 tablespoons unsalted butter, plus more as needed Now to make it 1. In a large bowl, whisk together the flour, sugar, baking powder, salt, and nutmeg. 2. In another bowl, beat the eggs and then whisk in the milk and vanilla. 3. Melt the butter in a large cast iron skillet or griddle over medium heat. 4. Whisk the butter into the milk mixture. Add the wet ingredients to the flour mixture, and whisk until a thick batter is just formed 5. Keeping the skillet at medium heat, ladle about 1/4 cup of the batter onto the skillet, to make a pancake. Make 1 or 2 more pancakes, taking care to keep them evenly spaced apart. Cook, until bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, and the undersides are golden brown, about 2 minutes. Flip with a spatula and cook about 1 minute more on the second side. Serve immediately or transfer to a platter and cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with the remaining batter, adding more butter to the skillet as needed. 6. Procedure for adding fruit to pancakes: Once the bubbles break the surface of the pancakes, scatter the surface with sliced or diced fruit, or chocolate chips, nuts, etc. Flip with a spatula and cook for 1 minute more, being careful not to burn toppings.

game-hours: 624.9
review: I've been playing TF2 since it released back in late 2007. It's like watching a child grow and loving every inch of it including its flaws. Initially, that's not how I felt... We all love babies b/c they're so darn cute and everything they do is acceptable because they don't know any better. As years go on, you start to see the cracks in the child and question whether you want to accept the child for who they are or completely abandon the child. That's how I felt about TF2 as it aged. Witnessing TF2 evolve to something you were dreading was like watching your teenaged child hit puberty. New weapons? Hats? Taunts? Monetization? What is this nonsense? Then it happened....Free to Play. I started to blame myself. Maybe I needed to invest more hours in the original content? I should have stayed home on weekends instead of going out with friends. I was really thinking outlandish things and pointing fingers at myself when the game took the free route. After 2-3 years of neglecting, I looked at TF2 and became nostalgic. I saw what it was once before and realized it's still the same game. It's still the game that I fell in love with since day one. I have accepted all of its hats, taunts and the fact that it makes more money than I do. TF2 has blossomed.
