game-hours: 943.6
review: I love this game. I love love love it. I started playing it around February 2014, when poor ROTMG got hacked a second time. I needed something to do. A friend I met through ROTMG and I started playing TF2 and we had a bunch of laughs. Before TF2, the most tongue-in-cheek FPS game I'd ever played was Duke Nukem3D. (Yeah, I played DNF, but I had to stop. Being a female, I couldn't take the egregiously overwhelming misogyny -- which says a lot, because I absolutely LOVE DN3D to this day.) Yes, Half-Life has humor, as do Unreal and Unreal Tournament, but the games' stories in and of themselves still take themselves seriously and take you to another place entirely. Once I started playing TF2, I became obsessed with it. I haven't experienced this level of obsession with "something" since I discovered the LEGO Bionicle sets back in 2001. Now, if you've read my review for ROTMG, you'll know I have OCD. It's not difficult for me to get obssessed about PC games; they're in my blood. But not every PC game I play compels me to research the heck out of the game's mythos, or read the wiki like I was reading a good book. SPOILER! SCROLL DOWN UNTIL YOU SEE THE END SPOILER TAG IF YOU DON'T WANT TO BE SPOILED! I'm VERy interested to know why the Heavy will not return to The Team. OKAY, YOU'RE GOOD NOW, THE SPOILER'S GONE! This is a gloriously violent and bloody game. You will see gibs, you will hear agonized cries of death all around you. But you will also hear people roar with laughter at how they just capped the final point in a round being just a Medic ubering a Heavy. You will laugh yourself when you see your fellow Demoman detonate the mass of Stickybombs s/he just launched around the Payload and watch the gibs fly (yes. I have experienced these myself -- and laughed hilariously). Unlike similar games, TF2 shamelessly acknowledges its violent tendencies and invites you to partake in them. So grab your Minigun and fall in with the Soldier, Scout, Spy, Sniper, Medic, Pyro, Demoman, and Engineer, and get ready to kill some people!

game-hours: 78.2
review: Despite the FPS genre being smashed into the ground with crappy games as of late and is WAY overdone, Team Fortress 2 provides a refreshing and action-packed experience for an otherwise overdone genre. There are gamemodes you can't find in any other FPS, the large variety of classes keeps the game interesting and suits any play style, the action is intense and addictive, the nonstandard weapons are fun to use and have their own unique twists (I, for one, like the Soda Popper: it allows you to jump insanely high after charging up at the cost of a much smaller clip size), and this game is 100% free! You can still pay money to get certain things if you want them, but it is completely optional, which I applaud. If your computer can run this game, what are you waiting for? Team Fortress 2 gets a +9 on the scale of -10 to +10.

game-hours: 500.4
review: Team Fortress 2 is a game by Valve, a company I'm sure everyone knows. The game is currently free to play, so the community is huge. It's great that Valve still frequently updates this game. You will find nice, friendly people on here but you will also find some over competitive players or even "trolls" that may ruin the game for some people. There are many different types of servers with things to do. You will find basic servers with red team versus blue team modes, but you will also find servers like death run, freak fortress, saxton hale mode, and more. One big aspect of the game is items and hats. I feel they are nice, and it can be fun to customize the look of you'r characters, but some people overly obsess over them. One thing I'm finding with this game, is that a lot of servers run ads. This is understandable, since servers can be quite expensive to keep up. Ads are one thing, but a lot of servers now seem to have pop up ads that you cannot click out of, unless you completely exit Team Fortress 2. These are servers I refuse to play on and I suggest avoiding servers with such ads. Having to completely exit the game just to get rid of a pop up ad is no fun. Most servers have an ad that may play when you first enter a server, and that will be it. If I had to give this game a rating, I'd give it an 9/10. This rating is obviously only towards the game and has nothing to do with my opinion on the community.

game-hours: 492.3
review: TF2 is one of my long time favorite games. I've been playing the game before it became free. My Brother has told me that I even played the game before different type of weapons came out, but I remember playing the game when different weapon types was just introduced. While I dont play the game as much as I used to, I can still hope into TF2 and still have the same level of enjoyment as I used to have. I like the Mann. Co store, you can buy weapons, hats, and cosmetics. What I like about this is that it doesnt make TF2 a "Pay to Win" type of game, where you can buy weapons and/or armor that will give you an advantage over other players. Different weapons ISNT an upgrade, but a subgrade. All different weapons has its advantages and disadvantages. I can hop into TF2 with all the gear that I havent bought, and still feel average against other players who may or may not have payed for their weapons. What I dislike about TF2 is its drop system. I dont typcally buy items or weapons in TF2, so I usually wait for a drop. Drops is so rare that I feel like Im playing the game for no reason when I want a drop. Weapons is the most common drop, and hats is the rarest. I still remember my first hat drop, it was amazing. I hope in the future the drop rate for items will become more common, so I can craft more items. Oh, and buying weapons in game wont let you craft them, you may aswell pay for the weapon or hat you want. I recommend TF2, it has a good community and has great gameplay, it will make you play for hours. I have played other Free to Play games, and so far nothing has topped TF2. I will continue to play TF2 until I forget how to use a Keyboard and Mouse.

So i'm just gonna give u the recipe for making waffles Ingredients: 2 eggs 2 cups of all-purpose flour 1 3/4 cups of milk 1/2 cup of vegetable oil 1 tablespoon of white sugar 4 teaspoons of baking powder 1/4 teaspoon of salt 1/2 teaspoon of vanilla extract Steps: 1.Preheat waffle iron. Beat eggs in large bowl with hand beater until fluffy. Beat in flour, milk, vegetable oil, sugar, baking powder, salt and vanilla, just until smooth. 2.Spray preheated waffle iron with non-stick cooking spray. Pour mix onto hot waffle iron. review: Team Fortress 2 is one of the best Free to Play Action Games out in virtual entertainment. This game is free; the illustration is not overpowering, but playful and provides a satisfying mood and the performance of in-game action and the game istelf is sensational. 9 classes to play and master and a myriad of maps and servers to aquaint yourself with. As a consequence, a perfect equillibrium of competition and playfulness is established; One of the most intruiging aspects of this game. Furthermore, once you become satisfied with your efforts in-game, your temptation for miscallaneous items and unusuals,stranges eg. will become un-challengeable. You might waste all your money on this game for virtual items, or possibly make a single investment and further expand your virtual inventory with virtual currency. The only downfall it seems, is the frustration of being dominated by players far superior than yourself, however, with time your skills will be able to fairly match those that were once your nemsis. In conclusion after over a thousand hours, I believe my experience is valid and dependable to give you viewers and other fellow Team Fortress 2 comrades an oppertunity to further appreciate and give an insight to Team Fortress 2. This is my absolute and mode game that I have ever indulged myself (or Runescape), even as fast approaching adult. I enjoy this game, and hopefully so do you :) Wishing you all success in your virtual endeavours! - Geebert

game-hours: 330.8
review: I would call it the best FPS ever made. For a modern game, it is very different from the rest on the market, and that's the reason it is so good. Given 9 distinct and unique classes, each with their own personalities and required set of skills, allows for both casuals and hardcore players to have fun. A lot of game modes, a lot of maps, a co-op mode, custom servers, balanced weapons and the fact that it's all free, means you should download this game. There's no such thing as pay 2 win. By playing, you unlock random weapons via the drop system, which are never direct upgrades to the default ones. Every weapon has it's ups and downs. You can use weapons to craft other ones as well. I could go on about a lot of many other things about this game, but you should find out for yourself.

review: Watch, as you throw bottles of pee on people to deal more damage! Watch, as you throw jars of milk on people to regain health! Watch, as you stop to take a bite out of a sandwich in the middle of a battlefield with rockets, grenades and fire everywhere! Only in TF2... So, where do I start??? Pros: - Amazing gameplay with loads of gamemodes that never get you bored - Graphics are cartoony, very unique for a First Person Shooter - 9 classes to choose from, each have their own unique abilities - There are a HUGE amount of weapons to choose from to equip to your characters - There are miscellanious items, such as shirts, gloves, hats, pants or boots, and even badges that you can equip to your characters to make them look snazzy - There's a crafting system - There are a variety of qualities for weapons and items from Vintages to Unusuals, and even Killstreaks - Ducks Cons: - Nothing at all, that's is how good this game is This game deserves 10/10 "Gotta move that gear up!"

review: I, honestly, don't know why I'm even reviewing this game. Those suck ), and diffrences in charactors. But ,I'll be honest here, if you think this game is ANYTHING like cod, and play it and start saying that cod is better, prepare to have your flame shield up, for you shall be hated. By everyone. Err... I think I have to explain this for anyone new.... Here we go, things that people do that don't work in tf2: 1) NEVER stay on that heavy as a medic. Your team will die, since you're just staying behind that fat guy with a big gun. At least heal your teams. Please ;-; 2) Those 'Meet The Team' trailers are NOT acurate. Scout can't dodge everything, Engies can't have more than one sentry, And so on and so forth. 3) Don't just move in a straight line, holding down your fire button with the flamethrower. You'll die. It also has horrible range, and can't be used it water (I'm looking at you, random noob who held down his flamethrower in the water on 2Fort. ) . 4) If you shoot that heavy holding his sandvich, ducking in the corner, prepare for both hate and death. 5) This is a review. review: One of my all-time favourite games, period. I bought it around the time it was originally released. The game is very well-balanced for the most part. The game has vastly changed since the original game but I enjpy the additions they have made to the game. I've never spent so much time playing the same map without getting bored. (2fort) (I started playing when it was Quake Team Fortress back in 99). I enjoy being able to customize my character now with cosmetics because it gives a sense of uniqueness to your character. I enjoy going Demoman and decapitating a plethora of players. If you enjoy non-sense, funny dialogue from characters, non-stop mayhem, a very well-balanced game for the most part, doing conga lines, etc. this is the game for you.

Lettuce 2 pcs. Cheese 1 big slice of ham How to make: 1. Put 1 loaf of bread on a plate for the base 2. Cook the ham and set it on top of the loaf after. 3. Add the 2 slices of cheese 4. Slice the Tomato and put the slices on top of the cheese 5. Add the letuce and top it off with the other loaf. 6. Slice the sandvich diagonally in two and to make it hold stab a toothpick for each part then add an olive on the toothpick. Eat.

game-hours: 709.6
review: This is the best FPS I have ever played. I mean, first of all: It's free, so You have no excuse to not have it in your Steam library (also let's acknowledge the fact that the game runs basically on a potato). Then, it's the only FPS that I've played which has amazing characters, not just some spunkgargle-wee-wee white soldiers with no story behind them. Let's talk gameplay. It's quite easy to learn the basics of the game, but mastering all the games gameplay aspects can take thousands of hours, and that's why the game is so addicting. If You find something You want to be good at, for example rocket jumping (one of my favourite aspects of the game), it might take you like twenty hours to just figure out the basics. Then like another hundred hours to get the advanced stuff somewhat down. The gameplay also offers incredible amounts of variety. All the nine classes have their own unique playstyles and the unlockable items help change up the pace and playstyle of each class even more. I do think that the game lacks in a couple of areas, but they're quite small details, and the good stuff this game offers by far outweighs the bad stuff. So, I think the game requires Competitive Matchmaking, so that the community held competitive scene would get some help at, you know, staying alive (uh-uh-uh-uh staying alive). That's really the only complaint that I have. I just really want VALVe to remember that this game still exists and that GabeN shines a little light on the competitive scene. Overall, this is my all time favourite game, and I can't recommend this game enough. I made this review quite short, but I hope it was helpful for y'all.

game-hours: 182.3
review: Anything above a 90 on the metascore is a title you should play. Team Fortress 2 was planned to be a FPS/RTS hybrid in it's early stages but turned out to be one of the most respected and solid FPS titles that doesn't want to be realistic or yet another military based game. The "non-photorealistic" rendering as per it's technical name, is system taxing. That machine on which Half Life 2 runs perfectly on, will see a dip in frame rates (and enjoyment) unless the system is able to handle the higher standards of graphics. The scandal of turning from a paid model into a Free 2 Play model, has people refusing to pick the game up again. The cost of the game was around $15-$20 way back when, and came in the ye' old Orange Box. Profits after doing so increased 2 fold, which is a little known fact. Don't be suprised if you see "Man Co. Store" a lot, which is the paid item store run by Valve. Enjoyment is sure to be found, as it's not really a FPS. The community still calls it a "hat simulator" to this day, thanks to the player class customization. Serious play isn't to be found here. Sit back and just play. Again this is another team based game with 9 classes to choose from. A multitude of weapons and other items for each class will allow you to stand out. 8/10
game-hours: 1994.7
review: Awesome first person! Sadly playing other games when missing the launch of this game! Mega sad face :( Awesome game 9/10.
game-hours: 358.3
review: Pros: 1. Game is free. 2. Runs on same engine as games such as Portal 2. 3. Microtransactions are available, but it is set up so that every weapon has its own pros and cons(just because you buy a weapon you won't be op), and you can find and craft them all just by playing the game fairly easy. Clothing and such is also available. You won't have second-class equipment if you don't buy anything. 4. Can waste your life on this game like I did and then sell the stuff you find and craft for cold hard steam store credit. 5. One of the most played games on Steam. Has players 24/7. 6. Game is fun. Cons: 1. You found free FPS perfection. You have nothing to look forward to in life.
game-hours: 1055.6
review: ITS FREAKKIN AWSOME
game-hours: 1114.7
review: TL:DR: at the end It was 2011, I had been wandering around best buy when i saw a box case for team fortress 2 for 10 dollars. I wondered why they would be selling the same minimalist game i played on the orange box on my xbox, so i wandered over to the computer section of the store and looked up why someone would buy it on PC. I found that the PC version had more than the 10 maps on the xbox version, it had differnt weapons to pick from and hats too, i thought oh what the hell, and got the game. I came home to set it up on my old cruddy toshiba laptop and as a result caused me to create a steam account, but it couldn't hande it, so i used my brother's laptop whenever he wasn't using it. I fell in love instantly. The multitudes of gamemodes, the custom maps and many achievements to get (and i was an achievement addict back then thanks to my xbox) kept me entertained. My brother got a virus on his computer and blames the custom maps i downloaded because of it (to this day, im not sure if it was the cause). So he didn't let me use it anymore almost a year later it was early 2012, somehow i convinced my brother to play on his computer again when i found out that a few months earlier the game became free to play. A ton of my friends began playing it which made it appealing again. When i came back though everything was about trading, not many went to achievement servers anymore, there were spreadsheets, and things that used to be worth very little (buds were 2 keys and bills were 1) were now jacked up in price. I got used to it though, and adapted to become a good trader, i even met a guy who i called my "partner" and we worked together to trade our way up, and it worked. We got a fireproof diary (which i still dont know what it does) out of pyromania. Despite me finding the deal, he wanted to hold on to it. And around that time i felt him becoming more hostile, I was kind of afraid to ask him to much out of fear that he would run off with the whole thing. And despite my pleads in saying that it would probably triple in value soon (it only doubled, but i was still kind of right) he decided to sell it anyway. And because of my conversations with him being too cautious, he only gave me 25% ( 5 keys out of 20) and i couldn't really do much about it. I was angry. So i created a scheme in which i created a fake account and pretended i had some crazy amount to offer him in a spycrab (look it up if you dont know what it is) and knowing him, he said he had an equal amount (which he didn't). I got lucky and i won it and just like i thought, he changed his name and did a bunch of other things to hide himself. I then used a new fake account (which i pretended was a steam admin of something like that) and told him when he was reported for the spycrab, i investigated and found that the bud he used to have was duped (look that up too). He practically bribed me to keep quiet and i got back a good share of what was mine. He still doesn't know i did this to this day. I lost my tf2 privalages again until late 2013, this year, when i got my own computer. And this was the best time of all for me. From all my previous trading i had a ton of items which raised in value while i was away, i decided (as i didn't need most of it) to do giveaways in different servers. One server in particular (sodahappy) i met a kind admin (still good friends with) who helped me do some giveaways using his admin powers, this influenced me to join the community and become a moderator (so i could do giveways). For a while it was fun. People didn't do the giveaways for only free stuff, but for the fun minigames it had. Such as one where everyone was locked in a small room and had to try and run away while i used a /zap function which killed them if i pressed a button while aiming at them. But then problems started to occur, my giveaways started to become out of hand as everyone was doing them. People no longer cared for the game than the prize. And i got in trouble with the higher up admins because of the amount of zaps ( i had 2800 zaps in the 4 months i was a mod, other mods had no more than 100 in their entire careers). After explaing that issue and a few others i was restricted in giveaways. And over time i got less enthusiastic with it. I left Sodahappy, but i left with a ton of new and good friends on my side who i met through the server. In the recent months i focused on getting my dream unusual (which i wanted long since before free to play was a thing). A texas ten gallon painted gold that was vivid plasma and level 3 or 33 (favorite hat, favorite paint, favorite effect and if you look at my name you can see why the level) After borrowing an entire bud from that admin mentioned above from sodahappy (the first one i met) i purchased the hat for 3.5 buds (with some extra sweets) while it was only worth 2.5. This was because the owner was super reluctant to give it up, but i needed it for its level 33. After paying off the 1 bud debt i felt complete I had a ton of tf2 stuff including my dream hat and i felt it was time to move on. So i gave a lot of my stuff away and stopped playing tf2, revisiting occasionally. Summary/TL:DR: Tf2 is my most played game of all time and i kind of grew up with it. And if i could go back and change anything i wouldn't (maybe except for that  scamming me). As much as it makes me sound like a nerd, Tf2 represents a chapter of my life and i wont soon forget it.

game-hours: 935.9
review: I had started playing TF2 when it came out in 2007. Me and my cousin would enjoy it for hours on end, and the community was just starting. I was addicted to this shooter, with its' cartoon-like graphics and simple objectives. Then all sorts of weapons and headgear/ misc items were released throughout the years, and the game turned into something different; an economy. It's hard to enjoy the game when it's filled with trade servers and all sorts of random junk, but it didn't stop me from finding some amazing communities. As time progressed, I started to get bored of the same old thing. Until I found new modded gamemodes like VS. Saxton Hale, Deathrun, TF2Ware, Slender Fortress 2, and more. My interest soared with playing these games, but eventually, I decided to quit. The community is heading downhill, and I chose to put my items in the market in hopes I can gain some money back. All-in-all, Team Fortress 2 is a great game, but is also a dying one. Hopefully something drastic will happen so I may come back to it.

review: This game................... I got it about 2 years ago, and at first I started playing, it seemed like a pretty fun game. I played for about 6 months, then it started to get old. I took a break for about a year, I started back up again after watching numerous Youtubers play (Jerma985, STAR_ ,ect.) and I have to say this is probably the most fun I've ever had in any game before. After years of playing Halo with my friends, this just brought so much new material to the table. Never in any game have I seen this much variety in the different 9 classes. This is probably the only game that I can step outside of spawn wearing a bubbling hat, go hit someone in the face with a fish, then get into a battle with a fish with a lightbulb sticking out of it's mouth as my weapon, and the foe has a frying pan, then someone else comes in with a ham! I highly reccomend this game for anyone with a sence of humor, and someone whos looking for a little change of scenery as I was. WARNING: MAY MAKE YOU GIVE UP YOUR SOCIAL LIFE AND SPEND HUNDREDS OF DOLLARS ON USELSESS THINGS.

game-hours: 2332.1
review: Team Fortress 2 is the greatest thirdperson MMORPG Action Scroller Platformer of the century. It features intense graphics and high resolutions unlike any other game. The sound quality surpasses all expectations, and when listened to closely enough, shall make you feel like you are in this completely realistic functioning game. Team Fortress 2 features an enormous arsenal of classes with up to 9 different weapons. The hats and accessories can be easily obtained, especially Unusual-Grade and Strange-Grade hats and accessories. These customization options give specific powers to the wearer such as improved gold pickup radius, and improved gold spawn rate. The story to the game is as magnificent as it has ever been and still is to this day. Taking place in the mid 600's, this game features the most realistic, futuristic, gameplay you have ever seen with your balled eyes. The singleplayer is the greatest you will ever see, offering a rich story and enduring campaign that lasts up to several hundred hours. As an enthusiast of the game, sporting up to 10 hours of gameplay, I know that this game is the greatest that will ever be played. It is currently up and running and ready for preorder today.

review: Team Fortress 2 is the ultimate free to play game. Its been going strong since 2007 and will continue to be a great game for many more years to come. Most free to play games are pay to win nowadays but Team Fortress 2 is different, its pay to have hats, and hats make you look stylish. You can also get jackets and such but hats are the . The gameplay it self is fantastic, there are nine different classes and each play a role in the game. Gradually overtime you collect weapons and such for each class and there are s of items in this game and they are still throwing out updates adding weapons, cosmetics, maps ect. The graphics arn't tood bad either for a game made back in 2007, it has its own style and looks overall great. Overall i think this game is a whole new take on FPS games and is better than most games you can buy so i rate this game 1010 incredibly enjoyable. game-hours: 488.8
review: It's freakin' TF2. Do I really need to say anything else? Okay, for realsies, TF2 is by far one of the most thilling, enjoyable, addictive, rewarding and downright fun experiences on ANY system. While this game may not seem so serious on first glance, the core gameplay and mechanics of TF2 are top-notch, the classes and their different weapons are VERY well balanced and the expansive array of different weapons and cosmetics for each class really gives you the creative freedom of making your class and playstyle truly unique. The classes on general are all well implemented into the game and all have their own unique playstyles, attributes, weapons and other. This means that there's bound to be a class that suits practically everybody's different styles of play and each class as a whole seems very well adapted to their uses for the team (e.g Medic used to heal/protect/assist team members while they do their jobs, Scout used to quickly get to control points and capture much faster.) The main reason behind why I find this game so fun and addictive is quite simple; Challenges. The game is CONSTANTLY rewarding you for attempting different game types, mixing up your game style, playing as different classes or something else entirely. This could be something as simple as getting a certain number of kills with a certain class or weapon or as challenging as accomplishing a series of progressively hard goals without dying. Even if you do eventually grow tired of the standard TF2 gametypes, the "Servers" feature allows you to search for a completely new and different way of playing a gametype or a new gametype entirely, such as Trading Servers, Medieval Mode, Arena Mode or anything else that the community of TF2 can think of. All in all, Team Fortress 2 has to be not only one of the most fun experiences on Steam, but on ANY console as a whole, thanks to its great core gameplay, rewarding challenges, well balanced classes and weapons and also its awesome and creative community. Even if you do get this game free-to-play, you'll immediately want to upgrade yourself to not only make your classes and weapons truly unique, but also broaden the already-deep amount of content on offer.

review: Okay, unless you have some operating system other than Windows, Mac OS, or Linux, you really have no excuse whatsoever to not own this game. I used to think I was not a fan of first-person shooters. I was wrong. This game has scads and scads of humor that kept me going through the early learning periods, allowing me to laugh off my failures instead of get frustrated at them. What I didn't realize at the time, though, was I was still learning how to play. And by the time the humor was wearing thin, skill was taking over. I might have only been classified as 'competent', but I wasn't mindlessly killing myself over and over. I was making a difference, even if just a small one, in each and every match. If you like FPS games, get it. If you don't, get it. If you want a hat simulator, get it. If you want a completionist's wet dream, get it. And best of all, of course, IT. IS. FREE.

game-hours: 713.2
review: Ingredients 1 1/2 cups milk 1 egg 2 teaspoons vanilla extract 2 cups White Wings self-raising flour 1/4 teaspoon bicarbonate of soda 1/3 cup caster sugar 25g butter, melted Method Step 1 Whisk milk, egg and vanilla together in a jug. Sift flour and bicarbonate of soda into a bowl. Stir in sugar. Make a well in centre. Add milk mixture. Whisk until just combined. Step 2 Heat a large non-stick frying pan over medium heat. Brush pan with butter. Using 1/4 cup mixture per pancake, cook 2 pancakes for 3 to 4 minutes or until bubbles appear on surface. Turn and cook for 3 minutes or until cooked through. Transfer to a plate. Cover loosely with foil to keep warm. Repeat with remaining mixture, brushing pan with butter between batches. Serve.

review: This is the most stupidly fun game ever made. Whether you're casually playing on a valve server, playing competitively, messing around in some crazy game mode on a privately hosted server, or trading, you're going to have a lot of fun. The only negative thing about this game is the name. A much more appropriate name would be Hat Simulator. Because that, my children, is the true purpose of this game. To buy, sell, and collect hats. review: This game................... I got it about 2 years ago, and at first I started playing, it seemed like a pretty fun game. I played for about 6 months, then it started to get old. I took a break for about a year, I started back up again after watching numerous Youtubers play (Jerma985, STAR_ ,ect.) and I have to say this is probably the most fun I've ever had in any game before. After years of playing Halo with my friends, this just brought so much new material to the table. Never in any game have I seen this much variety in the different 9 classes. This is probably the only game that I can step outside of spawn wearing a bubbling hat, go hit someone in the face with a fish, then get into a battle with a fish with a lightbulb sticking out of it's mouth as my weapon, and the foe has a frying pan, then someone else comes in with a ham! I highly reccomend this game for anyone with a sence of humor, and someone whos looking for a little change of scenery as I was. Slice the Tomato and put the slices on top of the cheese 5. Add the letuce and top it off with the other loaf. 6. game-hours: 492.3
review: TF2 is one of my long time favorite games. I've been playing the game before it became free. My Brother has told me that I even played the game before different type of weapons came out, but I remember playing the game when different weapon types was just introduced. While I dont play the game as much as I used to, I can still hope into TF2 and still have the same level of enjoyment as I used to have. I like the Mann. Co store, you can buy weapons, hats, and cosmetics. What I like about this is that it doesnt make TF2 a "Pay to Win" type of game, where you can buy weapons and/or armor that will give you an advantage over other players. Different weapons ISNT an upgrade, but a subgrade. All different weapons has its advantages and disadvantages. I can hop into TF2 with all the gear that I havent bought, and still feel average against other players who may or may not have payed for their weapons. What I dislike about TF2 is its drop system. I dont typcally buy items or weapons in TF2, so I usually wait for a drop. Drops is so rare that I feel like Im playing the game for no reason when I want a drop. Weapons is the most common drop, and hats is the rarest. I still remember my first hat drop, it was amazing. I hope in the future the drop rate for items will become more common, so I can craft more items. Oh, and buying weapons in game wont let you craft them, you may aswell pay for the weapon or hat you want. I recommend TF2, it has a good community and has great gameplay, it will make you play for hours. I have played other Free to Play games, and so far nothing has topped TF2. I will continue to play TF2 until I forget how to use a Keyboard and Mouse.

game-hours: 61.8
review: This game is a great multiplayer experience! I remember hating TF2. But my friends got me to try it out, and I fell in love with it! It's free to play, but if you're still hesitant to download it because of it's estimated download time, don't worry because Steam overestimates the time it takes to download. I remember downloading it took 30 minutes to 1 hour when the estimation said 7 hours. Either way, you can either play in team matches with friends, or random people who happened to be on the server. I prefer the Co-Op mode, Mann VS Machine. In Mann VS Machine, you can team up with friends, or random people as i said. It's pretty much a Human Team against AI Robots. The Human Team wears a red color, and Robots, blue. What i really like about Mann VS Machine is that you can buy upgrades. You get a certain amount of money before the game starts, and you can buy upgrades with it. After the game starts, whenever you kill a Bot, they drop a certain amount of money depending on how tough the bot was. Then, it's a race to ge the money first! I like upgrading the heavy from slowest class, to middle slowest. Either way, TF2 is worth your download time. It can't be worth yuor money because it's free to play. All joking aside, I really like, this game, and once you give it a try, you'll love it!
